Author: Deleted User
Content: Hello, my name is Johan van Holland and I am from Holland! (Netherlands) I have been active in production and sales in the food industry for 40 years. Mainly in the meat industry. There I saw how important it is to work with data. Mainly because it actually rarely happens. While this is often a winning push when making your quote. So now I am selling a SaaS operation at Innius. A platform for Iiot solutions. So we let the machines talk to the operators, managers and other stakeholders. (maintenace for example). Sales are really slow. In the beginning it is mainly relationship building. Even once it is installed, you still have to get used to working with data and data analyzes. (pareto analyzes for example) Now we notice an increase in interest in working with data and understanding your machines, OEE improvements, etc., as a result of the corona cricis. Margins are under pressure, so something must be done to produce more for less. More yield, less costs. So far my introduction!

Author: paulwright3831
Content: Hi everyone. Author: industry4.0
Content:
Thank you for the invite! 

Ryan Treece - Automotive Business Manager - IIoT & Industry 4.0 
Banner Engineering. 

I‚Äôm fortunate that Banner allows me to wear many hats in this role but my current primary focus is developing a network of integrators and partners to provide our customers turnkey solutions driven by our hardware.  Example: Call for parts, predictive maintenance, Covid-19 occupancy monitoring, etc.

The other half of my job involves working with our large strategic accounts to implement our hardware into an industry 4.0 solution.  This can include defining scope, hardware guidance/recommendations, network topology, cloud integration, new target markets, or new standard basic end to end solutions provided by Banner.  

Tl:dr I try to convince my engineers to custom build hardware for customers and then find people to turnkey it for us.

Author: evanwill.
Content: G'Day Folks! Yes, I am from Australia but immigrated here 8 years ago from South Africa. I completed an elec eng diploma at the ripe old age of 26 after working in the industrial painting industry and fell in love with PLC programming. I was a junior SCADA programmer and moved on to Automation Tech for distributor for Lenze in South Africa. I then moved over to tech sales opening the Cape Town branch for Beckhoff and then moved over to Australia and worked as a commissioning engineer on mobile machinery in iron ore and coal and then joined the sole distributor for Rockwell as a sales dude and moved over to application engineering (pre and post sales) a couple of years ago. I am addicted to technology and still get the same buzz working in industrial automation  as when I switched my first LED with a PIC programmed in assembler. When I am not scouring data sheets, tech videos, LinkedIn posts etc. you will find me cooking over fire (as is the South African way) and spending time with my family. #stokedToBeHere

Author: dep05d
Content: Hi everybody! My name is Dan and I'm an IT architect at a large global manufacturer. Over the past 10 years or so, we have established a sizable footprint of standardized SCADA systems across dozens of our manufacturing facilities, as well as a centralized enterprise historian/dashboard system tied to hundreds of production lines and hundreds more clients. We primarily use Ignition, having used the software since its initial beta, along with Oracle for the database layer. I'm very intrigued by the concept of the unified namespace and the transition to pub/sub to simplify architectures.  I'm also interested in discussing business system integration into the unified namespace, namely if transactional data exchange has a place here and could provide a path away from embedding business system interfaces into SCADA systems.  Thanks for the invite, @Walker Reynolds !

Author: marioishikawa
Content: My name is Mario Ishikawa and I'm the CTO of PackIOT, a Lisbon based Startup for the packaging industry, helping factories to be more efficient with our platform. I have a Bachelor Degree in Information Systems, as well as a Technical Degree in Electronics. I got this technical degree in High School and from there I joined a Brazilian SCADA company called Elipse. Then I went to college (Information Systems) and after college I started a company as system integrator. I have been working for the past 23 years with Software for Industrial Automation, mostly SCADA for Power Companies, but also Historian, MES, SPC and Traceability. So, I consider myself an IIoT Engineer Software focused. Two years ago I left my previous company to join PackIOT as a Co-Founder. I'm glad to be here with so many great brains. Thanks for the invite @Walker Reynolds ! I'm particularly very interested to apply and learn new technologies, merging IT with OT and to help this market to be more open and diverse. In my opinion very little changed on PLC/SCADA/MES/Historian from 1980 to 2010 and  I particularly think people are now watching the transformation of this market in the front-seat, and people like us from this community are actually driving this transformation. And the transformation is broad, not only technical but also as companies and professionals present themselves. Who would think 10 years ago we would have IIoT Vloggers? BTW, I love the content by @zackscriven (glad to see you here, I thought had left this world for good) and @Walker Reynolds . Regarding my content, I regularly write on my company blog and you also can see some more general articles on Automation World from 2 years ago: https://www.automationworld.com/products/control/blog/13319227/scada-and-edge-computing and https://www.automationworld.com/products/control/blog/13318762/brainstorming-the-future-of-scada-systems

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> I think it's just missing formal experiences. I freelanced and build SaaSs to finance my studies without useless internships at big companies.
@Deleted User Do me a favor -- rate your skillset in each category on a scale of 1 to 5 (5 is highest)

1. PLC -- Ladder Logic/Function Block/Structured Text

2. Python, Javascript, C#, Java

3. SQL

4. IIoT Protocols -- MQTT, DNP3, LWM2M etc

5. SCADA -- any platform

6. MES -- any platform

7. ISA-95

8. OPC-UA, DA, HDA

9. Ethernet-IP, TCP/IP

10. Network Administration (L1 - L3)

11. TensorFlow, other ML

12. Mobile App Development

13. Instrumentation

14. Business Intelligence

And send me your resume -- happy to give you feedback.  It is important to note that the Industry 4.0 professional is a hybrid, automation and controls on the far left of the scale, computer science, data science on the far right of the scale -- I 4.0 pro is in the middle with their feet in both worlds.  It is far easier to teach the automation pro the computer and data science than the other way around.  Though, you need both types of pros on your team.

Author: boyang6559
Content:
> that's why I will move to Switzerland next month for a software engineering position. However I don't give up and will love to share experiences and learn more to get a nice job for iiot!!
@Deleted User Hi, I had similar frustrations couple of times. manufacturer (big and small) asked us to research IIoT or AI tech for them, but when asking a proper position in the industry, the answer is always 'we are not prepared for a data scientist position in our business'. Me and other guys I know, meet these situation many times, and many of the talent and ambition lads left the manufacturing sector at the end. Recent, one of the top mobile app lead company has asked me whether interested in working with them to develop edge AI tech, with doubled+ pay. The tech is what we are developing for IIoT, but can also be used for mobile applications. I was very sad after this that the industry you love actually cannot treat you well, compared to the tech-intensive sector, like Google, MS, AWS. What I feel, Google, MS, AWS are marching on the market where GE, Siemens, PTC used to dominate... These IT companies actually can make hardware, e.g. Google's nest, FB's oculus...Once they dominated talent, and sooner or later they will start the invasion driven by capital needs,  these traditional industry vendors (especially who have large software sales now) have little chance to fight back. The way how industry software adopts IT tech is much slower than how IT companies adopt and change the industry business model. However, I hope industry guys can find a way to hold industry fields. Maybe one possible way is 'start-up', keep an independent way to develop these techs for industry users without limited too much by the 'culture'.   ü§ûü§û ü§û

Author: .dhess
Content:
Hello! Denton Hess, Vice President of lunchtime Gatorade Zero Sugar Thirst Quencher selection. I usually go with Glacier Cherry, but Glacier Freeze is also a favorite.
There are a lot of amazing people here. This group is awash with talent!
I‚Äôm brand new to Industry 4.0, and I am working to wrap my head around what we could be capable of achieving on my site.
My background is in the US Semiconductor industry sector. Currently I work in Washington state, and I love what I do.
Automation in my current fabrication plant is mostly fixated on interlocking process recipes with product runs to mitigate misprocessing. Most of our automation is focused on scrap reduction and specification adherence, via SPC modeling constraints (Brookside).
As an associate equipment engineer, I am much more interested in how my efforts contribute to an accurate OEE.
Much of our equipment set runs on a wide variety of different PLC manufacturers, proprietary single board computers (SBC), which may or maynot lash up to SECS (SEMI Equipment Communications Standard)/GEM (Generic Equipment Model) protocols. 
I‚Äôm interested in ‚Äúhigh bang for the buck‚Äù, ‚Äúmost amount of results with the least amount of effort‚Äù solutions that make for a killer ROI, so that my internal pitches are easily authorized.
I‚Äôm inclined towards massaging our computerized maintenance management systems (CMMS) so that it can support OEE, and in turn support the ERP / MES layer. 
I‚Äôd like to thank Walker, Vaughn, and their team for their awesome spoon fed, no nonsense information flow. 
Glad to be here, and in the tribe. Looking forward to getting my Nerd on, learning tons, and contributing.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Hi, Ben from New Hampshire. I coming into industrial automation with a background in control systems using microcontrollers (ARM, PIC, AVR, Arduino etc) using a lot of cloud connectivity.  I've recently joined the R&D team at a pulley manufacturer and a part of my role on that team is to bring in new manufacturing technologies. As I started to assess the current landscape of industrial controls, I came across @Walker Reynolds and Intellic Integration and immediately knew this is where we needed to go. Our manufacturing works very well, but most of our existing machines were built in the 1970s and haven't been updated since, just maintained. As we launch a new product line I am trying to move our company towards 4.0 concepts. Reception has been very positive so far.

My biggest gripe coming from my microcontroller background is how closed the industrial controls landscape is! It's infuriating trying to spec out equipment and software and not being able to get pricing and good specifications about how different pieces will play with each other. I'm really hoping the 4.0 openness will start to change a lot of these things.

Content:
Hello everyone. My name is John Cindrich and I live in the Cleveland area. My career has been mostly in manufacturing operations, quality, and continuous improvement roles. I really have little experience with industrial automation (other than one PLC programming course I took years ago). 
One thing I have always run in to when trying to conduct root cause analysis or run a continuous improvement project is the need to collect accurate process data. Getting to that data has always been a challenge, thus my interest in industrial automation. I found that either data is not collected, or I must beg for even read-only access to data so I can write my own SQL queries. While I am new to industrial automation, I want to transition to this field to help give other operations and quality folks the tools they need to do their jobs. Plus, I am hoping this will let me spend more time doing what I really enjoy doing‚Ä¶ writing code that solves business problems!  My intention is to use this mentorship program as a first step toward achieving my goal.

Author: roykok
Content: Hi everyone.  I manage Marketing for CESMII - The Smart Manufacturing Institute.  We are a USA government funded organization designed to help all manufacturers, but especially small to medium manufacturers, on their journey to Smart Manufacturing. To achieve that, we offer Education and Workforce Development, Peer Groups for networking, Funded Research, solving key automation problems and an Innovation Platform.  The platform is delivering a unified name space, delivering complete interoperability between applications and data sources.  We are focused on making the addition of analytics to an industrial automation system as simple as adding an app to an iPhone.  Nice to be in a group that has a common focus.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Welcome @Roy Kok - CC-Link Guy!

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Roy Kok - CC-Link Guy Howdy! Welcome aboard. Can that funding help poor mentees to become the integrators of tomorrow?  After all, we are all about education.

Author: roykok
Content: The funding of projects is very interesting, and something that integrators can take advantage of.  Our Platform handles the data exchange between applications and data sources.  It is a plug-n-play platform, because equipment is defined by Profiles (Data Models) and applications are built to recognize Profiles exposed by our platform.  We will also have a marketplace, where you can search for the applications you want (like an OEE calculation), download and install it, and the OEE APP will search for alll the equipment that it can work against.  No interoperability configuration work.  Here is a video on the concept.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDMLm1TmBjk  We are currently funding projects to develop Profiles for various types of equipment.  CNC Machines for example, or Robots, etc.  The biggest challenge facing manufacturers is the ability to scale from a pilot project to a plantwide or corporate rollout.  There is little economy of scale, when you have to create integration projects for a rollout.  CESMII is completely changing that game.  So, if integrators have clients that want to make a major leap in digital transformation, we have the solution, and we will involve integrators, even with funding, to create Profiles for the application.  Profiles eventually become CESMII value as part of our marketplace.  Profiles can also be private - don't have to become part of the marketplace, if there is proprietary content, but overall, the value of our marketplace for exchanging Profiles and the Apps that use them is what will democratize Smart Manufacturing for the 99% of small and medium manufacturers.

@Roy Kok - CC-Link Guy Love the concept -- my conversations with CESMII and about CESMII have been positive... however, I fear this approach is solution centric over technology centric -- and that is problematic for me.  I am doing a deeper dive and would love to discuss with you.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 1. Edge Driven 2. Report by Exception 3. Open Architecture are absolute requirements for successful deployment and scaling of IIoT and Industry 4.0 Digital Transformation intitiatives.  I am not convinced, yet,  that your platform is nothing more than the 'Connected Enterprise' approach +standards +community contribution.  I apologize for the critiquing approach, but the community has been promised a lot, by many companies, over the last 2 decades, and very few have delivered.  If CESMII and your platform are the real deal -- then you can handle the heat and the scrutiny and will come out shining.  Thanks for posting.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Hi. I'm Kell Kvist from Denmark. I have for several years been working with ERP, integrations, and data. As a Chemical Engineer, Master of Science, I want to have a holistic knowledge of process automation and all the layers - from the sensor to the cloud. My focus at the moment is identifying an approach and checklist to create an AS-IS baseline. My next step would be to establish a TO-BE template document. The documents must follow the "Walker Reynolds" approach. Looking forward to being part of this group. /Kell

Author: roykok
Content: @Walker Reynolds  - I agree with you.  We have a very lofty goal and are putting together the consortium to make it happen.  Yes, edge driven, yes report by exception, yes open architecture...  We are creating a proof of concept and very workable product for small and medium manufacturers to adopt and use.  But the magic is in our Profiles, and a marketplace to both share them and find applications/vendors that have analytics value against them.  We are shortly announcing a joint effort with the OPC Foundation, specifically for OPC UA, to create a marketplace for exchanging profiles.  While the OPC Foundation is creating many interoperability specifications for industries, we are creating the actual interoperability Profiles, the files that can be downloaded and applied in an application.  While CESMII will have an interoperability platform for others to use, we expect that leading automation vendors will adopt our Profiles and support them within their own product architectures.  So, that means you don't need to create data models that are different in every vendor's solution stack.  The CESMII Profiles will enable interoperability and instant value, in solutions with any number of vendor products.  It is a big goal, but we are also a Government Funded Non-Profit with this as our mandate.  We are achieving what no single product vendor can do.  And, for the price of a CESMII Membership, we are making the technology available for FREE at this time.   Walker, I think you will see value by exploring our technology in greater detail.  https://github.com/cesmii  Here is a demo of our Platform - https://youtu.be/j8fymUL55xk?list=PLtH3B3EUuDoqvih7Ka_WQKpKblGuB2gDs

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Thank you @Roy Kok - CC-Link Guy Im on it!

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Roy Kok - CC-Link Guy Who sets the Profile standards you are currently developing? Given the vast differences in equipment and applications do you anticipate a broad profile for a given area or many profiles each for a specific vendor?

Author: roykok
Content: Sorry for the delay,.  We have a pretty sophisticated scheme for the structure of our profiles.  There will be high level profiles that are general enough for classes of equipment Pumps, Motors, PID Controllers, etc.  Then there are extensions to profiles that can have much more vendor specific information.  In addition to the basic data models, profiles will also have definitions of what they can be used for, as well as definitions for protocols that may be needed.  So a Profile can specify that there are these tags that have these meanings and you'll need an ethernet connection with this protocol to get it.  Ideally in the long run, when you install an analytics app, it will auto-discover the profiles (equipment) it will be able to run with and will then auto-configure itself after receiving permission to do so.  Our profiles will become an industry standard and vendors will deliver equipment with applicable profiles.  System integrators can also create profiles and may choose to list them in our marketplace, the place to find and exchange profiles, and discover the apps that will work with them.  I should also highlight that there can be totally private profiles, should Intellectual Property be an issue.  Again, the goal here is to make software fully plug and play.

Author: sevensins2757
Content:
Hey all, I am Mo and I am a young systems integration/automation professional in automotive manufacturing sector, based in the Greater Toronto Area in Canada.  

I have almost 2 years of experience across the entire digital manufacturing tech stack, ranging from PLCs, SCADA, MES, Systems to ERP Integration. The technologies I deal with include ControlLogix, Ignition, SQL, DBs, OPC Middleware like Kepware and many more.  

I currently work as the MES Analyst for an automotive parts manufacturing facility and am responsible for not only support but also design+implementation of industrial applications in collaboration with system integrators, as necessary.  One of my main ambitions is to standardize and centralize data collection and storage so individual applications can plug into as necessary, rather than having data silos for each application.  I was watching Walker's IIoT and the idea of unified namespace intrigues and I would love to learn more about it as well as the latest in technology so I can add value to my facility. Looking forward to being a part of this community!

Author: sevensins2757
Content: It's hard to say since a lot of functions fall under the umbrella of MES.  I guess one video would be how we can create a modern, scalable,  Industry 4.0 MES solution for enforcing specific operations+processes on the factory floor(Quality for instance and making sure failed parts are rejected).  At the same time, the solution has to be integrated with SCADA/Controls without being monolithic and rigid

Author: sevensins2757
Content: I understand that in Industry 4.0 we try to not vertically integrate solutions like the ISA-95 and go for a more closed-loop approach, but that is also a challenge given what hardware/software is on the shopfloor

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hi, I'm Emanuel, 32, from southern Germany, I started my career in a german mechanical engineering company that is one of the major printing press manufacturers, where I did an apprenticeship in Mechatronics, worked there, on the mechanics, electrical, electronics, PLCs (ABB), sensors, hydraulic, pneumatic and electric actuators etc., etc. worked in assembly including installation, configuration and setting into operation  of automation equipment  as well as service.
Then I went for University, where I graduated in Mechatronics and Automation Engineering, lots of hands on automation labs in that, usually with Siemens tech in HMI/Visualisation, PLCs, Bus-Systems etc.
During college I worked first in automation engineering at a nuclear research facility with Siemens technology, 
then later I worked at a Software/Communications Engineering/Control/Embedded/HMI-Oriented company, 
where I stayed after graduation as well. 
At that company I did:
- FPGA development for Software Defined Radio SoCs in VHDL (plus C for the processor side)
- Controls development for a force measurement machine (PID-Controller / CAN-Bus / C++ / Qt for HMI on PC)
- developed an adaptive filter for clock recovery of a decoder firmware at a video-stream RF-Receiver to allow for lower decoder latency (better filter needed to allow for smaller buffer), prototyping in Matlab and R, implementation in C++

Author: Deleted User
Content:
- developed  a passive locating and tracking system based on radio signals, I chose how to do it and also implemented that (TDoA + bayesian estimation with a state space mechanical model of the systems to be tracked)
- developed a data science "solution" for haptic feedback system EoL data evaluation, starting form the raw data, and I set up a linux system, set up database, set up web dashboard, and did the processing/statistics/"data science" behind it.
- developed signal processing for force sensors systems (that is, measuring force fused from several sensors)
- developed end-of-line calibration algorithms for force sensor systems
...
Then switched to a major corporation, where I work in R&D Control,  Software Development as well as Software Architecture, for electric car traction drives, which ends up in ... a really huge number of cars, working now mostly with Matlab/Simulink and C and CANape, classic automotive embedded gig I guess, 
so I'm right now not employed in classic industrial automation.
Though as I already did stuff with it before uni, during uni and after, I'm still pretty curious, and see a future for myself potentially again in the industry (ideally IIoT/Industrie 4.0 related)

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hi everyone! I'm from Norway working for a additive manufacturing company as an automation engineer. I've been working with PLCs (Siemens, Bosch Rexroth, Allen Bradley) for 10 years, both in the field in the oil industry and as a programmer in manufacturing. I just joined your mentorship program. I came across your content while trying to understand more about OPC UA, and a fuse blew in my head. The way you communicate, with hands on knowledge and experience, without the fluffy sales lingo, was soooo refreshing. I've more or less ignored the Industry 4.0 and IIoT concepts for years, thinking it was just a fluffy way of saying digitization, and gone about my usual business. Now I want to know more about building a unified namespace, the technology and more. So thank you for blowing my fuse, waking me up from my 3.0 slumber! Looking forward to learning and sharing.

Author: richard44160
Content: Hello, I'm Richard Dousset. I'm working in France for Cargill since 2006 ! I'm the automation lead for oilseed plants covering EMEA region. Our plants are mainly based on DCS (SIemens PCS7). Cargill has started its 'digital transformation'. Smart manufacturing, data lake, app store, in-premise cloud: many initiatives are starting everywhere ! IT team is leading most of the initiatives as they are customer-related (ERP/CRM enhanced services) and this big team is delivering solutions very effectively (boosted by the pandemic!). OT transformation on the other hand is lagging a lot ! One small team is in charge to organise and architecture from plant floor to top floor across businesses. To make it easy, they actually plan to use Osisoft PI infrastructure already deployed worldwide to connect everything up to the top floor. When i started to discover industry 4.0 concept over internet content,  i cross your road, guys. And i understood that using PI as the solution is probably not the most effective ! I'm not sure if i can influence this but i definitively want to take the chance to learn from you and participate with the community to this 4.0 revolution ! Very exciting ! 50 years old but huge desire to learn and share ! I'm also looking at event-driven distributed open-automation based on IEC61499 ! Seems also very challenging - see new Schneider EcoStruxure Automation Expert !

I'm delinquent on mine...

Matthew Parris here. I'm an electrical & computer engineer that joined manufacturing in 2016. My¬†Industry 4.0 journey started in 2018 when I attended a Gartner conference. I will forever be grateful for that conference, for that is when their buzzwords, hords of confused IT participants, and lack of actionable information motivated me to skip their sessions and scour the market myself.¬† Enter OPC-UA and MQTT/SparkplugB.

I have only started reaping the benefits of standardizing equipment interfaces and am continually looking for ways to improve systems. I stumbled upon some low-budget YouTube videos a year ago that were reminiscent of a classroom, learned some things, and now I'm very glad to have landed here. :smiley:

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve checked out the mqtt FB and library in an S7-1500 and concluded that I could not use it to make my S7 plc primary communication mqtt. I would have to parse strings to values and a lot of effort. So it would be more time efficient to use opc and an IoT gateway of sorts to get the plc to ‚Äútalk‚Äù mqtt. Am I missing something? Is it the same mqtt function block that is used for 1200 series?

Author: MEE6#4876
Content: GG @Jon Forbord, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I haven't done any MQTT in the 1500, interested in the answer.  The 1200 integration is pretty straight-forward, though.  Important to note, for the most part, we use a native Siemens driver to pull the registers and convert to MQTT with a gateway.  A very common integration is PLC --> Ignition or FactoryStudio via Siemens Driver --> MQTT Transmission in Ignition or FactoryStudio --> MQTT Broker.  The other option I really like is PLC --> WinCC-OA via native driver --> MQTT Broker ; WinCC OA still has some work to do but they are moving in the right direction.  It still remains to be seen if they are going to vendor lock to Mindsphere or go the 'node in an ecosystem' approach.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content:
The Unified Namespace is the single source truth for all structure and events within your manufacturing enterprise.

The UNS is both omniscient and omnipresent -- that knows everything and it is everywhere.

To learn more about the Unified Namespace... watch this video here. https://youtu.be/PB_9HIgSCWc

Author: mparris
Content:
Welcome!

My understanding of digital twin is weak. The best use-case I've heard of is a machine learning algorithm representing a real-world item that predicts future value based on current data, or someone could use the machine learning algorithm to do What-If analysis, allowing them to play with the component purely in the digital space. I suppose the desire would be to take this to the plant/line level.

Would be interested to hear how you guys use Digital Twin

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Welcome Thomas! Do you have some interesting cases to share on IIoT?

Author: thjaeckle
Content:
Our most common use cases are actually in the residential IoT. There you have digital twins for eg your smart home devices and you interact with the devices always via their twin, ensuring proper authorization and also other aspects like eg setting configuration, even if the device is currently not online/receiving at the twin which the device can later react on once it connects again.

Simulation is also a common use case, in a way to already interact with APIs of the twin, even if a physical asset is not yet available.

We also like to talk about "device as a service" as our focus is mainly deployment in the cloud and using APIs of devices should be made as easy as consuming a simple (web) service.

Author: arpitshrivastava
Content:
Arpit Shrivastava here from India, üôÇ 
I am a part of the team of ambitious Engineers here at InfiIoT Technologies, We make products which help make life easier for people, farmers, and workers. I enjoy doing projects which help digitalizing processes, on topics such as IOT, Smart Factory, Smart Machines (basically Industry 4.0), and learn new things on the way.

I am specializing in Power Electronics Design, PCB Design, and Manufacturing, Industrial IoT, 3D Printing Technologies, Computer vision, AR, VR, MR, Django, and Python programming. Motivated to learn every technology which comes across.

I am an Astrophile (I specifically follow SpaceX, Nasa, ISRO, Boeing, and BlueOrigin), I am a people person.

Author: _wwerner
Content:
Hi there üëã 
I'm Wolfgang. I've been developing enterprise software (financials, automotive, biotech, manufacturing) for the last two decades and specialize in solutions running on the shop floor since 2016-ish. I helped a manufacturer of solid carbide milling cutters to digitize their manufacturing processes from oder entry to mobile manual work logging to analytics and machine learning supported pricing of custom tools.

I'd like to learn how others build resilient, highly available solutions for the shop floor. Especially interesting to me is how people feel about primarily cloud based solutions and the convenience / data protection / reliance on 3rd party services / failure impact zone trade-offs. 
Essentially, I'm interested in how people deal with this dichotomy: While cloud based solutions offer a great deal of convenience and often work great, shouldn't we be very conscious about the risks they pose, too?

Disclaimer: I'm a Developer Advocate at Actyx, a startup building a factory software development platform.


Happy to be here, looking forward to talking to you guys and learn from your experience.

Content: Welcome @wwerner!

Author: zackscriven
Content: Welcome Wolfgang! I think you will learn a lot here!

Author: faithware101
Content:
Hi Everyone ! 
My name is Gnichi Mohamed,  I have been working as an embedded systems engineer for the last ten years. I think @Walker Reynolds#8594 's mission is very inspiring. I had to replace siemens s5 plc by an industrial PC as my first engineering project and boy that was a lot of work, We had to create a bullet proof linux image that can boot quickly,  we had to work with Qt to make the HMI from scratch in C++ and we had to make an R script that calculated machine metrics for the maintenance and the quality employees of our client that generated  pdf reports. Now there are several Open Source solutions that might helped me do that quicker. Today I use thingsboard and Mqtt to connect sensors and s7-1200 and I build modules that leverages thingsboard api to generate alarms and SMS messages. If you have any questions about thingsboard, I am happy to answer !!

Author: johan_jeppsson
Content:
Hi y'all!
I'm Johan Jeppsson from Sweden. I work with IIOT in Europe. I had started my journey in a different point but it lead me to design the same architecture that is mainly discussed here. Today it's a fact that exception reporting, or pub/sub architecture is very effective decouple / to let several consumers get access to and analyze data generated anywhere. I found that the same architecture was the best internal architecture for a solution we had developed, but breaking appart the solution / application into it's pieces let us to deliver it to anyone having the pub/sub architecture (simplified).
Looking forward to the exchange of information!

Author: sampath2806
Content:
Good Morning My name is Sampath , I am an IT professional from India with an Electrical Engineering background and IIOT, Industry 4.0 enthusiast.

Decade and half back worked as trainee in a heavy Power equipment manufacturing plant for a period of 18 months.

Observed few problems
For Plant/Quality/process engineers spreadsheet was best tool to track and record  daily/weekly/monthly activities, consolidation them was a daunting task  and it's the same today.
ERP is an alien subject for them.

New gen plant operators feel the current job as sluggish, slow and its very difficult to motivate them as they are in smartphone gen and this requires work culture change.

Plant Operators with decades of experience  and close to retirement,  were unable to do KT to new gen workforce,  due to lack of tools and data.

I believe IIOT , Industry 4.0 will address these problems and also these skills will be a differentiating factor to my career.

Author: mohammadmot
Content:
Hello every one,
My name is **Mohammad** and I have 15 years worth of experience in enterprise software development mostly in telecommunications. 
The project was an ultrasonic solution for pipe leakage and damage detection and it was five years ago, that I started my journey into the industrial application programming. Somehow, I fell into the orbit of industrial embedded solution development and never left.

As an entrepreneur, I focused on** digital transformation** three years ago. That is successfully IoT enabled a factory and securely tunneled all the data to a unified name space for further analysis and visualization. 
The biggest challenge right now is the volume of* big data* generated and stored in cloud, hence I am developing an **edge solution **to filter and preprocess data.

Last, thank you for this opportunity, looking forward to learn more from y'all, specially @zackscriven and @Walker Reynolds

Author: mwhale.
Content: Hi My name is Matthew Whale. I work for a startup that builds lithium batteries for aviation and other high reliability applications. I am just a technician but I have pioneered the acceptance testing processes used there. The company is getting read for real manufacturing and for FAA certification of several products. I am trying to push the organization to use more automated processes and software and now appears to be a good time to start figuring out what that should look like. I am learn how to use PLCs but mostly I have worked with NI test and measurement equipment and I am not a fan of NI software or NI in general. I am hopping I can find PLC solutions and software solutions that can bring the entire organization into industry 4.0. Right now the company is about 100 employees, in about 3 years it would not surprise me if the comparny was more than 3000 employees. so, I would really like to find solutions that scale. In about 2 years I will graduate with technologist degree (BS) with a minor in MIS. I hope to simultaneously be working on getting upto speed on and integrating edge enabled PLCs with Tatsoft or Inductive software solutions into the new production systems. Right now so few software solutions are working well for my organization. I would like to recommend to my management an entirely new ISA95 set of software solutions ERP, MES, SCADA and Field level solutions. I am rather ignorant of the limitations of the possible solutions for example I have not found any PLCs that are LXI compliant or support any IVI drivers that are common in the test and measurement community am I just going about it wrong? If anyone one is willing to hold my hand and point out the obvious and less obvious solutions I would be grateful. so... that is why I am here.

Author: zackscriven
Content: You are in the right place. You‚Äôll definitely want to join our mentorship program. You will get a lot out of the PLCnext training workshop alone. Also I‚Äôd recommend joining our Mastermind Program. This would equip you to be the solutions architect for your company.

Author: wired4coffee
Content: Marty Reyes here from Holland.  That‚Äôs Holland, MI located on the shores of Lake Michigan.  I feel like a small fish in a lake of big fish here. My hope is this fish will become an IIoT trophy catch. My background, well I come from the dark side.  :(. Yep, solid background in IT.  My last job 5 years ago was in IT as a systems administrator.  However, I‚Äôve since seen the light and been in automation generally on the network side of things.  I‚Äôve worked with PLC‚Äôs, HMI‚Äôs, switches, routers VPN‚Äôs and such, but I was always drawn to the IIoT. Of course,anyone doing research on IIoT is going to stumble across Walker and Intellic.  To be honest, I didn‚Äôt stop with Intellic.  I continued researching and found many companies.  Kept coming back to Walker‚Äôs videos to cross check other approaches to IIoT.  Hands down, the Reynolds approach is solid and while others are looking to sell licenses, Intellic seem to really want to help the automation industry move to 4.0 and beyond.  That parallels me and what I want to do, hence, here I am.  Looking forward to this and open to any suggestions for success.

Author: Deleted User
Content: This is Jost from Germany. I am product owner and responsible for the  devleopment of a monitoring system for rotating equipment in the process industry. Walker was a great  inspriration for us to go the MQTT path. I am here to get a deeper understanding of OT architectures (today), how our product fits in there best and being future-oriented at the same time. I am glad to share what we have learned during the dev process e.g. MVP results and especially customer responses to our approach.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Welcome, Jost! What kind of monitoring do you do on rotating assets? There is a lot of activity around wireless vibration monitors and ML software for predictive analytics. Curious how your solutions fit into that.

Author: Deleted User
Content: A quick shot: wireless is one option but does not provide the signal quality required for proper vibration analyses for critical assets. As for ML: We¬¥ve implemented Neural Network algos and Fuzzy Logic two decades (!) ago and enhancing its failure pattern recognition capabilities continuously. However, I do not believe in the hype around real (!) prediction of failures in complex machinery. There are much too many external and internal parameters that change within seconds but influence your prediction model massively. What works is prediction of linear condition changes, e.g. wear. (This is quite simple compared to the Marketing statements that are  flooding the industries.)

Author: pyrygronholm
Content: I'm Pyry, COO at Prosys OPC Ltd.  I have been working with Industrial Internet since the 1990s and nowadays mainly creating solutions, which are based on OPC UA. In our company, we of course have also OPC UA SDK and applications. While the best practices to integrate factory floor to IT, I'm especially interested in discussing the real-world experiences in this area.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
Welcome @PyryGr√∂nholm  !
You may find that the people in this community view the OPC-UA a little different than you do. And that they find it unfit to be the backbone in an IIoT ecosystem.
But no worries, we will be happy to guide you in the right direction.

A really nice place to start (unless you already has done it) is here: https://www.iiot.university/iiot-mini-course

Author: pyrygronholm
Content: Well, although I do understand a lot of critics towards OPC UA, I'm still confident that it is the only possible option for a unified standard, mainly due to the already achieved adoption, to integrate OT and IT. Any other way would be a mess of several competing standards like it's in the field bus world.  But in general, it's, of course, great to have many opinions and open discussion.  I will take a look of the Mini-Course at some point during my current vacation. Thanks!

Author: pyrygronholm
Content: To my mind, it enabled big players  lock-in customer to buy everything from one source.  Of course while different buses have different capabilities, it also gave some sales arguments, why we are better than others. As most buses are just good enough for typical use, I would say the first argument and politics were then main factor for the "bus war". But the above is of course just my thought as total outsider.

Content: The answer is different product requirements.  You've got to be careful thinking a single technology is a solve-all.  Hardware evolves much slower than software in this space and you don't want to get yourself backed into a corner and locked in with no exit strategy.  Good luck!

Author: zwgrounded
Content: Hi everyone - I'm Zack (https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachary-weintraut-1788aba0/) and have about 3 years of experience designing, programming, and administering the construction of instrumentation and control systems for water and wastewater treatment projects. My academic background is in Chemical Engineering and Materials Science. My favorite class was, no surprise, Process Control Dynamics. In school I conducted novel research in using electrochemical oxidation techniques to disintegrate persistent textile dyes and perfluorinated carbons (surfactants i.e. that non-stick coating on your frying pans). My best IIoT achievement was doing the field maintenance, calibration, and initial big data cleaning (python) for a reinforcement learning algorithm (bunch of PhDs did the RL part) used for the early detection of any one of the 60-some EPA-regulated persistent molecular pollutants known to exist in surface water intake systems. I'm a diehard Algonaut (yes, blockchain) and Pythonista. My favorite book is Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzche and favorite Netflix series is Peaky Blinders. I love pondering how I could make the world a better place for us all. Moreover, I've come to love the conceptual idea of this community. Second to last, I want to highlight the first @Walker Reynolds video that I ever watched (couple years ago), the one that prompted me to tread further and further into this community - https://youtu.be/0aWmrvHPmBs. Two weeks ago, I had scheduled my team to receive a demo of Phoenix Contact's (PC) PLCnext system. Low and behold, the PC reps had actually brought up @Walker Reynolds and Industry 4.0 Solutions in the call. Fast forward to now and lastly, I'm now in possession of a PLCnext starter kit and am thrilled to share this news with the community here.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Hi Zack! Thanks for sharing!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Welcome Zack!  It is quite exciting to have you as a member of our community!  Blessings to you!

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hello believers of the 4.0 movement, 
my name is Ron, I'm an automation engineer in my early 50ties working as a business development and innovation manager for one of the biggest electrical contractor in Europe. We are used to work with the tech provided by the big automation OEM's and ofcours, we do have verdor partnersships with them in the industrial automation and IT stacks. Actually, I've worked 15 years at Siemens, selling plc/scada/mes products and consultancy to 3.0 system integrators for bigger projects in none primary automation markets, like large infrastructures, etc.. I had the opportunity at Siemens to have good discussions to the productmanagement in Germany, also here, you learn about the dynamics behind this. I can assure you, while enjoying a couple of beers, I can share a view good stories on how not to close tech or function gaps in a future proven way, this ofcourse from a customer pov ;-). My first open architecture experience was with Simatic IT and later WinCC OA, the last one I introduced into the Belgium public infrastructure market.  The last 2 years I gained some experience as a project lead for some 'digital tread oriented projects' (try to use your terminology :-)), reasonable succesfull in getting insights bottom up, but having a hard time on getting information and adoptio  back to the workspace (70k employees) in an affordable manner. It actually hurts seeing available budget burned, delaying other hard needed tracks.
As a proude father of 4, I'm specially blessed with 2 daughters, native from Ethiopia. Because of them, I was able to experience first hand what a none industrialized and no middle class society looks like. So, I fully relate to Walker his mission. We owe this to our next generations. 
Impressed by the openess of Intellic's youtube videos, expecting a lot of inspiring discussion in this community.

Author: marioishikawa

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Hi, all.  Rick Bullotta here.  Long time industry software person. Author: koios6274
Content:
Hello all - excited to be a part of the team.  My name is Brent, and I've been in IT for 15 years, with a focus in Industrial Automation for the last 8.  I used to work for a Systems Integrator, and now work for an end user. I took IT experience + a bachelors in Mechanical Engineering and went into Control Systems.

I've spent a lot of time doing site assessments focusing on the network architecture and building out road maps for what you have, where you are, where you want to go, and how to get there. I've been certified / have experience with most major SCADA platforms (Ignition / SystemPlatform / InTouch / Rockwell ME/SE etc) and have experience programming with AB PLCs (PLC5 --> ControlLogix).

I've done a lot of consulting with corporate IT groups and essentially been that IT/OT Bridge. I speak corporate IT and have many Cisco/VMware certifications & experience with Hyperconverged systems / building out Industrial Datacenters.

I'm here to continue to learn and to take things to the next level. I think there are a lot of companies that talk about I4.0 and attempt projects and things don't tangibly happen.  I'm in a position now where I can influence things at a local plant level, segment level, and ultimately the enterprise.  

Thanks!

Author: dvy___
Content:
Hello all, I‚Äôam Davy, currently based in Shanghai working for one of the big European SI‚Äôs. I‚Äôm leading our automation and industrial software business for our customers in China. We focus mostly on process industry (pharma, food and fine chemicals). For Industry 4.0 the core of our work focuses on getting the production orders from ERP, executing them in the PLC/DCS, and then sending the finished production data back up to the ERP or separate databases for further analytics and processing. (Yes that‚Äôs basically the area of MES but we sometimes end up with this setup before anyone even mentioned that word üôÇ  )
Since most of our business is in process industry I‚Äôm very much looking forward to the Open Process Automation initiative that will break down the silo‚Äôs that are holding back a lot of innovation in our field like devops, automated testing, ‚Ä¶ .  (Why can we do those things for a simple web app but not for a vaccine production line ‚Ä¶?) I highly recommend following their progress, and also people like Don Bartusiak from ex-Exxon who‚Äôs now trying to build a business around it.
Another topic I‚Äôm working on is mixed reality and the third paradigm of computing, which will allow us to put scada interfaces and workflow on our equipment and in our plants at the physical locations where it makes most sense. Skip Zuckerberg‚Äôs Meta keynote and dive into some of the dev sessions to have an idea what capabilities are coming. In Industry many have already been disillusioned by the Hololens but the near future will be headsets with full-color optical pass-through like Lynx (10 days to go on their kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/stanlarroque/lynx), project ‚ÄòCambria‚Äô from Oculus/Meta and probably Apple‚Äôs upcoming high-end glasses.
Always happy to discuss any of above topics!

Author: douga.7429
Content: I am making the pitch today to the VP of IT, after spending 100's of hours watching 4.0 content.  Our SAP first Supply Chain Transition has been put on hold as they try to get it back on track by putting new PMOs on it.    Last week, I dropped a bomb to the CFO at an all-hands IT meeting, stating that Digital Transformation should be a familiar term to our organization, typical coming before an SCT transformation.  The dozens of SCT members have no idea what that is or who would be crazy enough to speak up like this.  If 4.0 doesn't resonate, I don't think it will get me fired; it would be the catalyst that likely forces me out.  You and Walker have been the best resource for strategic thinking, and I am thankful for that.  If it does resonate, I am going to need more help. I don't think we will be able to drive this through IT.  Walker once gave a presentation about how to present to board members.  If you can offer materials and advice, it would be welcome.

Author: chris.demers
Content: Hello! I'm a Principal Scientist at Catalent Pharma Solutions where I seem to have found myself in a position of driving their digital transformation strategy. Catalent is a Contract Development and Manufacturing Organization (CDMO) best known for doing vial filling and packing for the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson COVID vaccines, but we also manufacture specialized treatments (biologics) for mid to large pharma companies.  I don't have any formal background in automation, but I'm a PhD engineer by training and I've always enjoyed automating repetitive tasks be it simply moving data around seamlessly or setting up pumps and tubes to sample bioreactors at regular intervals. The 4.0 Solutions YouTube channel has completely changed my view on our old digital strategy, and I'm currently trying to get the company to sponsor my participation in the Digital Mastermind program, so I can become fluent enough to influence senior level IT and Operations teams. Really looking forward to participating in this community and bringing some perspective from the Biomanufacturing industry (which, as a whole, is not all that digitally mature - particularly small to mid size CDMO's).

Author: mithun.chandra
Content:
One communication standard for all OPC UA for AutoID devices.

 Communication with the reader is standardized, and the communication protocol is set to OPC UA. Thus the integration flexibility is achieved on the application side. Implementation of the RFID part, with the AutoID specification can now easily connect the RFID readers and integrate them for the Industry 4.0 requirements 

AutoID compatible readers are available e.g. from Harting / Siemens /Truck.

Author: torenorh
Content:
üëã  Tore Norheim Hagtun here, happy to be joining the community from way up north in Arctic Norway¬†ü•∂ 

Having worked hands on in the range from 4-20mA to mobile apps in heavy industries for the last 10 years, my main interest is making time series data available, understandable, and social for (industrial) teams.

Main lesson learned being that if we want to turn data into sustainable action and innovation, we need more diversity in understanding data and decision making. Data can't only be available for a select few specialists and developers. I care deeply for making data a useful everyday tool for the whole workforce. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre building¬†clarify.io,¬†a place where teams come together to explore, discuss, and enrich streaming data. We‚Äôre a team of 20 developers and data scientists based in Trondheim and I‚Äôm CEO and co-founder, together with @Tor-Inge and @bernt . 

I have a masters degree in cybernetics and robotics, but I‚Äôm probably one of the worst programmers on the server üòÅ  I‚Äôm more of an "how to apply technology in the real world" type of guy. Have lurked around here for a while, but hope to connect with the community more actively, learn from all of you great people, and contribute where I can! And¬†if you're ever visiting Norway, be sure to reach out for some insider tips. Me and @Anders Gustav can take you paragliding as a start! ü§ù

Content: Hi everyone and Happy New Year. I'm Harry originally from Ireland, currently based in Switzerland. I became interested in IIoT before I had even heard the term üôÇ this was due to my interest in the construction industry where I completed a Masters for Information Technology in Architecture, Engineering & Construction in 2017. My research focused on enhancing Smart Building Energy  performance using a customized digital performance monitoring tool. I'm more broadly interested these days in applying Industry 4.0 principles across multiple sectors, but I find its use in Smart Cities & Manufacturing most interesting. I'm looking foward to the Mentorship program and learning from the best üôÇ

Author: sambonator
Content:
Hello my name is Sam, from California, USA.  I'm new to discord, so still trying to figure this out. 
I've been working with AWS and IoT for the last couple of years, and have a few projects with AWS Greengrass working.  Since our corporate IT Infrastructure is 75% AWS, it made sense for us to begin our projects within AWS.  With the new Greengrass 2.0 platform, we will be able to begin using separate MQTT brokers other than the one AWS provides as a component.  We're beginning to explore HiveMQ-CE and Sparkplug B which we hope to use to standardize our messaging.  We also may look at VerneMQ or any others folks may recommend.

I have a background from selling statistics, BI and predictive analytics software and now been learning a lot about OT and industrial automation as I joined Clarify 6months ago. I'm here 100% to learn from all of you to understand the challenges and opportunities in the industry better. Most of my free time I spend with triathlon training and xc-skiing üôÇ

Content: Welcome Sam! There are several recommended brokers. HiveMQ, EMQ, VerneMQ and Chariot are the predominant ones. I will also use Mosquitto, but only for testing.

Content:
Thanks to Mario Gonsales Ishikawa for inviting me. I think David Schultz was actually the first person to suggest I join, but I somehow missed what what David was talking about. This a cool group. I am new to the Industrial Automation world and really like this industry. So vital. You can see more about me at https://scadaskills.com/daniel-bezden

Sometimes people are surprised by the jumps I've made from one industry to another. Making it through the Ignition University training is challenging. I have found that the key to mastering a new subject is making sure one knows the words of the subject. Here's a recent post about that https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6897692427814006784

If you know anyone working on their Ignition Certification, please feel free to pass this along.

Looking forward to learning more here and making more friends!

Daniel

Author: chrisbixler
Content: Hi All. My name is Chris Bixler and I have been on the corporate/production side of manufacturing for all 17 years of my career. I am a mechanical Engineer by degree with a Masters in Engineering Management and have split the line between process engineering, IT management, and plant management. The past 4 years I have been working in Plant management/General Management roles.  I made the jump to plant management thinking I could get more technology projects moving but I quickly learned the day-to-day operations get in the way. I am looking to transition out of production and into a role where I can help companies deploy smart technology to improve overall business success. I am incredibly passionate about technology and have deployed at least 1 new system at every stop along the way. I love data mining, excel/dashboards, automation projects, MES and process movement, and sensor integration to name just a few areas of interest. I am looking forward to meeting many of you and chatting about the future of manufacturing and potentially finding a new career along the way!

Author: silverfei1565
Content:
ü´êBy AMAü´ê To whom it may concern.
  The Key to making an over unity Electric generator work is mechanical advantage. In this case the mechanical advantage is achieved by getting the electric motor that is spinning to be able to spin a quantity of separate vertical discs that are connected to devices that generate electrical current while spinning to generate more current then the electric motor needs to spin. One of the ways to achieve this without violating the laws of thermo dynamics is to exploit magnetic field effects. To do this,attach a horizontally positioned disc to a bar the motor is spinning. You then place magnets on the top of the horizontal disc that the electric motor is spinning in a way that makes it so while the disc is spinning around, the magnetic fields are pushing upwards onto the edge of the vertical discs they hit into, forcing them to spin, thereby generating electric current. To get the magnetic fields to only hit into one of the edges of the vertically positioned discs, just put a material under the vertical disc that keeps the magnetic field from pushing against the disc until it reaches that one open spot where the magnetic field can hit up against the edge of the vertical disc, pushing it into a spin. In this way, the magnetic fields will be forced to do work that the electric motor wont be doing. This is how it's possible to achieve an Over Unity Electric generator.
 Extra Note: If anyone uses my ideas for none profitable means great I hope it helps, but if they are used to gain profit in any way I want small amount of royalties of anything that comes out of it please. üôÇ  My e-mail is starfire7654321@yahoo.com
 ü´êBy AMAü´ê

Author: tomt4914
Content: Hi, my name is Tom and I am an automation enthusiast.  My passion is where computers connect to the real world.  I got a start in HVAC automation as a controls technician (Automated Logic Corporation).  That started as the basic technician stuff and moved to IT/network support since it was all getting web based and they needed a network guru to interface with our customer‚Äôs IT departments.  From there, I moved into a role with a district energy system (central heating/cooling plant distributed via hot/chilled water to a city/campus).  My main role is IT, but I interface closely with OT.  I built an Ignition system for visibility to our plant networks in 2012, and have been adding to it since.  It‚Äôs been an important piece of our operations.  While I don‚Äôt consider myself an OT expert ‚Äì I‚Äôm familiar with most of the big industrial automation players.  I enjoy system architecture ‚Äì IT and OT ‚Äì and I find Industry 4.0 a great way to frame and talk about the goals.  In my spare time I like to tinker: Arduino, rPi, Home Automation, MPCNC, 3D Printing, etc.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Hello Everyone! Vatsal here, Co-founder & CEO at Litmus (https://litmus.io/). 

I started my career as an Industrial Automation Engineer at Rockwell, developing ladder logic and SCADA screens! Saw a wide gap in the market around the Industrial Data Infrastructure (Data Access, Analytics & Integration). 
Founded Litmus in 2014 with a couple of brilliant guys to solve that challenge. We built fantastic products, pivoted from Cloud-first to Edge-first, deployed countless times, met some brilliant customers/partners, and had lots of learnings on the way. 

Looking forward to the discussions in this community. I am pretty opinionated against legacy, insecure & other medieval stuff dragging the industry backward üôÇ

Hi Everyone, my name is Dennis and I am a developer working for a Dutch systems integrator. As a company we have a long history in industrial automation specialized in the food sector and the drinking water and waste water treatment. We used to do a lot of PLC/SCADA stuff but the last years we are expanding our self's in the MES area and the connection of OT and IT to help our customers improve their processes and give them insight in what they are doing. My self I did PLC / SCADA for a few years and after that worked on custom applications (mainly C# .NET) to collect data from PLC's. Calculate all kinds of KPI's and presenting them of dashboards. A year a go we found out about Walker Reynolds and the UNS concept and together with our team we are trying to figure out how to apply this to our customers over here in the Netherlands.

I have been following this Discord for a while now but thought it would be time to introduce myself and start interacting as well.

Author: petersorowka
Content:
Hi Everyone, my name is Peter and I'm the CEO of Cybus. Personally I'm an engineer, a father of three kids and a sailor ‚õµ 

Cybus is a German software company and we provide Cybus Connectware, an on-premise solution for the Smart Factory data infrastructure. We act in the middleware layer and are strongly convinced that smart factories should be seen like big micro-service architectures which benefit from strong decoupling between data akquisition and data usage. Cybus has it's very special positioning very close to the IT, because we believe you have to make the IT your friend, not your enemy. With this goal in mind, our software is focussed on auditability, infrastructure-as-code and IT automation. We enable a DevOps like deployment experience for the complete stack from PLC connectivity, data preprocessing to data distribution.

Technology-wise, we are based on containers, work very well in high-load and high-availability scenarios on Kubernetes and we have only open interfaces, everything configurable via REST, data accessible via MQTT but of course also with connectors to many legacy protocols, databases, Kafka, the clouds...

Personally, I'm very much interested in the technological transformation that we are seeing in the industry and how IT departments start to take over responsibility over shopfloor data management. I believe data infrastructure as a shared service is the only way to make rollouts economically feasible. I'm also curiously observing how different players act, and both factories and suppliers simultaneously try to define the tech stack of tomorrows factories - when will they ever realize that it's a bad idea trying to compete on the gateway layer?

Looking forward to interesting discussions here!

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Welcome Peter! That is very interesting. Looking forward to know more about Cybus.

Author: alexanderbattisti
Content:
Hi, my name is Alex and live in Germany. I am currently responsible for a system that (among other things) integrates power plant sensor data with customer demand data, weather and energy market forecasts etc. pushes the realtime(ish) data through a linear solver to calculate (and write back to the DCS) the optimal set point for our power plants, creates market orders with our trading partners for day ahead and intraday energy markets and potentially recalculates the optimal setpoint based upon feedback from our trading partners. I am here to learn more about the OT side of things, because the communication between DCS and cloud seems to be surprisingly difficult coming from a traditional IT centric software development background. 
Best
Alex

Content:
Hey hey all! I'm Edip, 27, live and work in germany. I work for a SaaS startup around production digitization / machine connectivity. Recently came across @Walker Reynolds I4.0 rant on youtube, very refreshing to see that we're not alone with this problem üòÇ üëè 

We have many prospects initially turn down our service because they "already have a digital strategy" which consists of:
- an expensive ERP program
- maybe even a MES system
- but literally no machine data besides: "machine is running", "not running"

They calculate OEEs and conduct analyses based on 0 insight, wondering why they can't understand what the hell is happening on the shopfloor. Happy to discuss if you see any progress in that matter since the video was posted 3 years ago. Cheers ‚úåÔ∏è

Author: maks.piechota
Content:
Hi, I'm Maks, senior software developer of wide range of tech stack. I used to work as C embedded developer, C++ embedded developer, C++ desktop app developer, API integration engines, web/cloud backend dev and I know some frontend frameworks (but I would not say I'm an expert there).

I'm looking for ways to utilize my wide knowledge and Industry 4.0 seems to be the best place for it as it both exciting me and has high demand and low supply. Thus I'm experienced from hands on writing of very detail oriented low level for loops and ifs conditions in different languages, high quality code with best practices TDD and SOLID and more to architecting web solutions in cloud, I want to step out of this role and take higher level role, e.g. like onboarding companies with new  technologies and mentoring their teams.

So I have two questions:
1. Is Industry 4.0 a good direction for highly experienced software developer with knowledge of software development cycle, project management and wide technologies understanding, but with little familiarity with industries line?
2. Is there a place to start a software company in Industry 4.0? Is it possible to compete with large corporations that work with industry decades?

I really appreciate your work guys, I have already watched hours of your videos in just two days lol

Author: johndevenney
Content: Welcome, Maks! Yes you can compete with the large corporations. Learn the digital transformation, technology stack, open architecture that Walker talks about, and you can compete with better quality at a lower cost.

And why managing user permissions would be a hurdle for me? Do you mean me, personally or this is something everyone struggles with?

Author: brianpribe
Content: It‚Äôs something everyone will struggle with. Many software solutions don‚Äôt integrate well with existing user permission services (windows authentication).

Author: terrancesmith
Content: Thanks for the welcome.  ThingWorx is a great platform for general purpose IIoT. Honestly.  It struggles in a few areas(price, the large company that owns it, UI, and scalability).  I kept using it because it was familiar. It was just easier to keep delivering high quality work without learning another tech stack.  I think ThingWorx was a market leader for a while, but the gap between it and other alternative platforms and architectures is closing.

Author: cameronhuber1932
Content:
Hello, my name is Cameron Huber.  I‚Äôm an Industrial Engineer by profession and have worked in manufacturing for over 20 years with a focus in process engineering and managing technical teams.  This month started a new position as a Technology and Lean Facilitator for Canadian Manufacturers & Exporters (CME).  ‚ÄúCME is Canada‚Äôs largest trade and industry association, and the voice of manufacturing and global business in Canada, directly represents more than 10,000 leading companies nationwide. More than 85 per cent of CME‚Äôs members are small and medium-sized enterprises.‚Äù  

Think there is a lot of overlap with what Walker talks about regarding building middle class jobs in America.  With the United States and Canada being such good trading partners it would seem we‚Äôll lift each other up the better we are.   From my understanding Canada is lagging behind in a number of areas compared to the US so we've got to step it up. 

Very interested in Digital Transformation and have been soaking up Walker‚Äôs/Industry 4.0‚Äôs content, it‚Äôs been eye opening and has altered my mindset on a number of areas already.  The technology stack vs software stack and the unified namespace is the biggest one.  Since Advanced Manufacturing, Industry 4.0, Digital Transformation is all in my scope, I want to ensure the fundamentals and my mindset is sound before attempting to guide and help other companies.  Passionate but fairly new so ‚Äòbig ears, small mouth‚Äô is my guide.   Lots to learn and glad to be here !  Thanks.

Content: We're glad to have you here Cameron!

Author: roykok
Content: Haven't updated you folks in a while.  You may remember me from CESMII.  These days I work for Mitsubishi Electric, managing three key areas - CLPA - CC-Link Partner Association is the global organization that manages the CC-Link protocols and supports partner adoption.  CC-Link IE TSN is the highest performing OPEN industrial Ethernet solution, leveraging the new Ethernet Time Sensitive Networking standards.  I manage the Mitsubishi Electric e-F@ctory Alliance Partner program, an opportunity for device and equipment vendors to join and access the Mitsubishi Electric ecosystem.  Lastly, I work with ICONICS, a leading SCADA company.  This one is especially interesting as I have spent a significant part of my career with SCADA software and I can attest that GENESIS64 is some very exciting technology.  GENESIS64 is a very powerful set of tools, designed for system integrators.  The tools let you take advantage of data models, and the solution is fully configurable, largely a no-code environment.  You want to code, have at it, but with GENESIS64, standard functionality works in 99.9% of applications.  Lots of acceleration tools for development and the configurations are stored in a database that you can directly access, should you want to create your own rapid development capabilities.  Application reuse is the name of the game.  This is a platform you can build your business on.  Some interesting options include AnyGlass (HTML5 graphics), 3D Graphics, BridgeWorX for MES integration, WorkFlow, Notifications, AnalytiX, etc.  With a history with Johnson Controls, GENESIS64 is the leading solution for BAS.  With the history in Process, GENESIS64 is a leading solution delivering scalability to over a million tags, and reliability through redundancy.  There is a remotely managed Edge solution as well, IoTWorX is a gateway solution to publish data to the Cloud with Store and Forward.  An awesome solution for equipment builders that want to offer remote management services.

Author: sdeggans
Content:
Howdy, everyone!
My name is Shawn Deggans and I live in Hurst, Texas - it's between Dallas and Fort Worth. 
I've worked in technology for 25 years. I've moved from working on web applications in the earliest days of the internet to becoming a cloud solution architect on Microsoft Azure. 
Recently, I left a consulting firm where I had worked for 4 years as a solutions architect to strike out on my own. I have a small company named Green Nanny LLC. I want to build up a practice in the Controlled-Environment Agriculture space with a heavy focus on small to medium sized growers. 
My technology focus for the last 3 years has been on IoT and Edge development mostly on Azure, but also using some products like InfluxDB, Chirpstack, and Mosquitto. I know C# well, and enough Python to create regression models, and I'm actively focused on learning Go. 
My most valuable skill is around working with people to transform desired business outcomes into tactical solutions. For this, I use the modern stack of Domain-Driven Development tools and interactive workshops to turn strategic business ideas into tactical architecture. 
I'm excited to learn more from this group and offer any help I can.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Welcome to the community Shawn! I too have an LLC focused on small to medium size businesses (more general/automotive manufacturing). What are some of your projects you got to work on utilizing azure, influxdb, and mosquitto?

Author: sdeggans
Content: Thanks, Brian. I‚Äôve had the fortune of working on a few projects using those technologies. I‚Äôm using Influx right now to capture time series data for a piece of manufacturing equipment that has about 60 different data points. We‚Äôre hoping to use the data for predictive analytics. Azure‚Äôs been my go-to cloud platform for a while, so I‚Äôve fully exercised its IoT stack. I really like IoT Central for small projects and it now has an Industrial mode. Mosquitto and PostgreSQL have become my primary MQTT platform lately. I‚Äôve designed a smart bathroom solution for a small airport, helped a device designer build a fluid dynamics capture device, and I‚Äôm lined up to start a project soon for asset tracking. How about you? What‚Äôs your favorite stack?

Author: donpancoe
Content: Hello everyone. I am a long-time electrical engineer who, in an earlier part of my career, had a chance to do some automation projects with Wonderware and SLC500 PLCs. I then got a late Masters degree in Industrial Design and veered into consumer IoT product development and entrepreneurship, starting first a consultancy then a consumer brand. COVID was not kind to that brand, and I've been again doing automation consulting for another startup that I met on my journey. This time with CompactLogix PLCs and Ignition. In the interest of making more forward-thinking decisions for that client, I came across the United Manufacturing Hub, which led me to this Industry 4.0 Community. I am now hoping to further rekindle my old automation experience, updated for the modern day, while merging it with my entrepreneurial experience of the last few years.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Good morning, Mark here. I an a EE by training, I've been working in Automation, on and off for the past 20 years, but non stop for the past 10. I'm a pretty competent industry 3.0 integrator, PLC, HMI,SCADA with an understanding of database systems. 

For the past few years I've been involved at various levels in Digital Factory/MES initiatives. I am currently working as a solution Architect.

I'm hear because I need more skills and knowledge to really add value for people I work for. 

They say if you only have a hammer everything is a nail. And I have been using Industry 3.0 to solve a customers problems. And I know that will solve today's problem but make it harder to solve tomorrows problem. 

I can't create an Industry 4.0 solution on an Industry 3.0 architecture. 

So I'm looking to learn enough to build an Industry 4.0 solution, and the harder part I'm looking to learn how to help people understand that.

And I know lots about HV engineering and power plants. Or I used to at one point.

Author: joshuastover
Content: Welcome to the Community Mark!

recently worked to build a MES like application for our internal manufacturing process using Python-FLASK framework and SQL at the back end, however, came up short on the choice of technology and mindset of the plant-floor vs that of board, this led a search of sort towards transforming my understating of architectures necessary to build a solution that's reliable and easy to scale. 
I came across I4.0 by accident and realized that i'm up against a mountain of knowledge and requires transformative thinking to scale it. I hope with this community, I can be a small cog towards transformation of the industry to the I4.0 age

Author: mass_5
Content: Hi, I'm Alexis. I'm currently doing my master degree in Industrial Relations in Quebec, Canada. For my master's thesis, I'm doing research on the implementation of digital technologies within the rubber transformation industry. My main goal is to describe how these technologies affect organization of work on the shop floor (skills, tasks, supervision/autonomy, participation of workers, etc.) and to identify specific institutional variables (labour law, labour market, government subsidies, etc.) that have impacts on managerial strategy, union strategy, HR practices, collective bargaining and the general social relations in the firms, including power relations and politics, surrounding digital transformation in the manufacturing industry. I am mostly relying on qualitative data, draw from interviews with actors at the sectoral and the plant level. So I'm more on the social sciences side of the subject and I don't have any engineering/technical background, this is why I've joined this discord server hoping to grasp some of the technical/management knowledge you share here. I'm sure I'll find insights from your discussions!

Author: joshuastover
Content: Glad to have you here Alexis! Look forward to you joining in on conversation.

Content: Hi All, I'm Steve, Tech CEO of Deviceroy. We make a small device called Aria that can connect most machines to IoT, turning them into a modern connected IoT machine themselves. We're also one of the first devices already certified on the new Amazon Sidewalk.
