Author: jpt5
Content:
Greetings everyone.  I am John Paul. Over the past 15 years, I've been deeply immersed in the IT and networking field. I've held positions such as Collaboration Team Lead, Senior Implementation Engineer, and Senior Network Engineer, which has allowed me to gain extensive experience in working with Cisco Collaboration products like Unified Communications Manager, Unity Connection, and IM and Presence Service.  I was given the opportunity to acquire a few Cisco Certifications including the CCIE and travel the country deploying networks, data centers, call centers, and video conferencing solutions.  

One of my proudest accomplishments was developing an automated system for a large school in California. This system streamlined the configuration of Active Directory, Google Workspace, Cisco Unified Communications Manager, Cisco IM and Presence, Cisco Unity Connection, Cisco Routers, Cisco Switches, and Juniper switches. I wrote the system using Python and integrated it with SOAP, REST, GAM, local Linux commands, SSH, Telnet, RPC to PS, and several other odd things to automate six different applications. To acquire the skills needed for this project, I relied on resources like videos, LinkedIn Learning, Cisco Training, and RealPython.

I was also able to program a directory and configuration report interface using mkdocs with markdown and diagrams. This solution visualized configuration and voice flows with the help of mermaid, making it easier to understand and maintain the system.

In addition to my Cisco expertise, I've also had the opportunity to work with Microsoft technologies and VMware. I've been involved in numerous projects where we transitioned clients from physical servers to virtual environments, optimizing their infrastructure and resource utilization.

Interestingly, I somehow ended up in industrial automation with a focus on biogas cleanup and conveyance. I have really enjoyed learning about industrial automation and controls along with IEC 61511 and many of the ISA standards out there. Diving into this new area has been both challenging and rewarding, and....down right humbling.  It is interesting to jump into a whole new world and be a newb all over again. Lol  

Lastly, I am highly addicted to AI and have been using every model I can get my hands on to make things easier for myself or to just make some really funny content.

Author: joshuastover
Content:
Hey John Paul! Welcome to the community! üòÑ

I love the problem solving mentality. It's impressive what you were able to do for the school. What AI platforms are you using? We talk a lot about the advent of AI. Many members of the community have been adopting using AI. It's incredible how far it's come. Things like ChatGPT are practically the only thing we're talking about in the #ai-and-ml channel now.

Once again, welcome to the community, and we're looking forward to getting to know you better!

Author: aimax888
Content:
Hello everyone! My name is Dirk. I'm a qualified German lawyer with an International MBA. For the past 15 years, I've worked in senior management and sales roles for smaller organizations that did not yet embrace digitalization. At the same time I have been observing the transformative potential of industry 4.0 and AI. This disconnect has fuelled my desire for a career-change.

My immediate goal is to assume a new role in an organization actively promoting digital transformation and helping companies to become industry 4.0 companies.

Although I lack a technical and engineering background (my professional training as an electrician for mechanical engineering dates back to 1992), I'm eager to learn and acquire the necessary competencies to quickly become an effective member of a professional digitalization / integration team.

Recently, a friend introduced me to 4.0 Solutions and recommended Walker's videos, which provided me with practical and insightful knowledge of the subject matter. However, I'm still lacking guidance on potential paths, suitable professional roles and required competencies to make such a career-change work.

Therefore I am reaching out to the community and I would greatly appreciate your feedback. What is your experience? Did any of you successfully navigate a similar or comparable career change? Or do you know somebody who did? Could you recommend a suitable path, including suitable organizations and functional roles for such a career change?  I would greatly appreciate your insights and advice. Thanks and best wishes!

Content:
Hello, I am 29 with a highschool diploma. A year ago I was hired by a small IoT company to do some assembly. After that I was a "marketing" intern and spent three months doing "market" research. On the same day I came in to tell the boss marketing wasn't for me and I'd work for free if he let work on something programming related, one of the programmer's quit so he said yeah sure go do that.

Six months later, while searching Youtube for a video explainer of how MQTT works, an Industry4.0 podcast showed up high on the search results. This is the first reasonable content I've ever seen on industry 4.0, and it doesn't come from a single company pitching some product that requires a marketing team to prove it's not useless. Blah blah blah, happy to be here and hopeful to actually talk to people about this stuff.

Hello everyone,

Author: daveconroy.
Content: Hi Everyone, I have worked for an integrator, an oem, and now an end user over the last 25+ years.  My current job is in pharma leading a controls and manufacturing systems teams which spans what would be level 1 thru 3.  I'm leading a program to bring I4.0 thinking, and solutions into our supply chain (which includes manufacturing, warehousing, and distribution) to improve our operations, connect shop floor data to the rest of the business, and reimagine our systems landscape.   I first encountered the concept of IIoT or industrial internet working on supply chain strategy back in 2016 but it seemed like a bunch of buzzwords with little substance.  I became an evangelist for I4.0 in late 2021 after watching some of Walker's videos on the UNS which led to some more intensive research into the topic. The I4.0 space had exploded over the intervening five years and I was hooked.   I'm looking to connect with others to talk about educating business leadership on the seismic shift that is occuring  and build the case for I4.0  in our organizations.

Author: remco.poelarends
Content:
Hello Everyone on this community, I am Remco, almost 25 years of experience in Automation in different sectors ranging from Medical systems (CT and X-Ray), Logistics, Smart Energy Grid to the last 10 years in Industry as a System Engineer for special machines for different customers. Apart from designing unique one-off systems for unique production processes I have always been interested in standardisation (because I hate doing things twice) and am leading and evangelizing the standardisation of the mechatronic design of industrial systems (including control) within the company and involved in different international projects researching transformation to Industry 4.0 / digitization.
The concept of the unified namespace as core of a solution I find very interesting and I believe in using one single truth to stay agile, flexible and independent.
I hope to learn more about the concept and how parts of the concept can be applied on different levels of automation.

Author: joshuastover
Content:
Hey Remco! üëã

Welcome, and thanks for the intro! Your experience in Automation is awesome. It's great that you're championing standardization in mechatronics and exploring unified namespaces for Industry 4.0.

Is there anything specific you are wanting to know about Unified Namespace?

Author: remco.poelarends
Content:
Over the last years we have developed a standard language (ontology) describing the equipment, process and material, you could call it a "unified namespace" on system level (and inside) also used to monitor and control the system (a sort of "real-time" digital twin). I am curious whether (parts of) the UNS could or should be applied inside the system and use it to monitor and control the system and in the same flow this information can be distributed to upper levels.
Further I am curious about modelling the UNS, is it similar to model/domain driven design?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Hi Remoco, in regards to modeling we recommend following ISA 95 part 2. You don‚Äôt have to follow it to the tee, but certainly covers most general manufacturers needs (imo). What I think really separates the UNS from digital thread is the concept of a node-ecosystem. Every service/device (ERP, MES, PLC, AGV) is a node that produces and consumes from any node. Of course security is a big requirement, but there are ways to manage who can see what.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Thanks, Brian.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: What you have described here is ontology and information modeling at the process level, which is a sub-set of a UNS.  Brian is correct -- the typical model is a semantic hierarchy based on ISA-95 part 2 -- Enterprise/Site/Area/Line/Cell -- it sounds like your ontology would fit nicely into this structure at either the Area level OR as a namespace under the Line/Cell levels.  This is a deep and long discussion -- @CarrieWaltman  or @Vaughn Turner will reach out and they can direct you to the resource best suited to go through the crash course -- either internal or external.  If you have an example of your ontology, that would help.  If you haven't already, you might want to take the free iiot mini course on iiot.university -- it goes over most of the foundational principles.

Author: remco.poelarends
Content:
First of all, thank you so much for all the fast and thorough answers, it feels like a warm bath to join here.
Second, it feels like we are on the same page and good direction already, we use S88 for the decomposition of our systems combined with a standard functional categorization and apply this as said on the complete mechatronics keeping strict borders between the physical model (what a system or component is capable of) and the procedural model (what a system should do to execute a specific process) to keep building blocks fully generic and applicable in all unique systems.
Further, we are more and more in contact with customers wanting more data from the systems we build and we could help with in-depth knowledge of the system and process (in the form of a digital twin), however customers are varying and some have applications in place like ERP and MES, some do not have parts of this at all or build parts themselves. Starting talk and discussion about Industry 4.0 is very hard most of the times.
Are there any demo's or cases to get a customer in the right "thinking" direction?

Author: vaughnturner
Content: Hi @Remco Poelarends thank you for sharing. We have some material that can point you in the right direction. Your last sentence says it all. You have to approach digital transformation as a mindset change, not only in what is possible, but in the way you will conduct, and run your business everyday. This is why it is so important that organizations have a digital strategy upfront, before starting to piecemeal solutions to plug the gaps. I'd be happy to share some of the resources we have available.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Digital Transformation starts with education -- there is a process called Digital Transformation Maturity Assessment that serves 3 purposes.  1. Fact Finding and baselining for organizations -- where are they, where do they want to go, what do they think their problems are, what are their actual problems?  2. Define Digital Strategy (the why an org wants to be digital, how data will become the primary commodity), digital architecture, minimum technical requirements. 3. Concurrently educate on what digital transformation is, what iiot is, what industry 4 is -- score their digital maturity and suggest a PoC that demonstrates value while continuing the education.  Too many vendors, partners and orgs put the cart before the horse -- it is critical to lay the foundation first.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Walker Reynolds, you just advanced to level 16!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: If an org wants digital but can't tell you what their digital strategy is -- stop and start there.  Do absolutely nothing else without a Digital Strategy.

Hello everyone,

I'm currently writing my Master's thesis and I'm looking for people who I can invite for expert interviews. The core of my thesis is to analyse the specific challenges of implementing Industrie 4.0 use cases although enabling technologies might suggest a high TRL and, based on this, to derive a "Industry 4.0 Use Case Maturity Model". Exemplarily challenges could be: Limited Data availability (according to the criteria of 5V) or an Unsuitable Manufacturing Environment (e.g., light conditions during Computer Vision based inspections).

In total, I have identified 3 example use cases that I would like to analyse. I have already analysed corresponding case studies and now want to use the interviews to verify whether the challenges of these case studies I have identified correspond with current manufacturing expertise.

I am therefore looking for experts who have or had touch-points with the implementation of one of the following 3 use cases:
Condition Based Monitoring & Predictive Maintenance for Manufacturing Equipment.
Autonomous Material Handling Systems (can be e.g. the autonomous recognition of products so that a robot such as a Celluveyor knows where to move the respective product)
Autonomous Defect Recognition and Inspection

I would be very happy to hear some feedback and am looking forward to an informative exchange. :ismile: 
If you are interested, you are welcome to contact me via Discord or Linked In: www.linkedin.com/in/tinus-veltel

Best regards,

Tinus
MSc Student in Intelligent Manufacturing Systems (University of Warwick)

Author: .red.fox
Content:
Greetings. Friends call me Johnny. When I joined the Discord, I wasn't planning on introducing myself or becoming active simply because I didn't have anything useful to share. Reading and gleaning was my goal, but I have now come to a point where I could use some advice and guidance, so here we go.

About myself: I started off my career by taking a 2.5-year college course in Business Information Technology after which I worked as a full-stack web dev in a team of 4 for 3 years, developing a custom web app for a local accounting company. I then got hired by my current employer as an IT (don't shoot me just yet). This young family business is a small manufacturing company (~20 employees) that is currently transitioning from manual labor to automating tasks.

How I found Industry 4.0: I was tasked with finding an ERP system since all of our processes are running on Excel sheets, and inventory management was nonexistent. During this search for an ERP that would suit our purpose, I stumbled upon an interview that Walker Reynolds had with Erich Kimberling from Third Stage Consulting. It did not take very long for me to be convinced that this is what we needed. In one of his videos, Walker talks about building a technology stack and not an application stack, and this is what really caught my attention.

Author: .red.fox
Content:
I am currently more focused on the IT side of things and making two of our applications (MES and ERP) communicate. I have barely any experience in the OT world (a little bit of S7-300 and ESP32) but will probably be doing more of that sort as our production floor becomes more automated. A lot of the content I find on System Integration (which I understand most of this to be) is focused on transitioning existing legacy systems and not so much on building new systems from scratch (correct me if I'm wrong).

We like to build all of our stuff in-house and learn as much as possible doing so. My boss is willing to invest in education, and this is where I would like to get your help and guidance. Where can I best learn how to build our application stack and the UNS with 4.0 best practices? I did the IIoT Mini-Course, MES Bootcamp, and MES Advanced - ERP Integration, but still don't feel like I'm ready to build this thing.

Much appreciated.

Author: stefanbucher
Content:
Hi
You have no idea how excited I am to finally have found what I was looking for. But lets start from the beginning:

Due to the shortage of skilled workforce on the labour market i got into this business. Everything I know, which I deem is very little, is self taught. Still it was enough to get hired - almost a year ago - by a startup. OK, I actually got asked if I want to join the team by the CTO and co-founder (I think he will join shortly ;-)) as we have known each other for a long time and he knew I was into building my own server environment and amongst other things, leveraging smart home devices. I actually have a Masters degree in Environmental Sciences. So feel free to ask any questions regrading environmental sciences. My knowhow in systems integration may be small yet but I love to share what I know. My expertise so far lies mainly in the area of HMI/EDGE and Databases.

The last year was rough in an exciting way, long hours, a lot of fun, perceverence was a keyword ;-). Starting from knowing basically nothing in industrial automation I have learned a ton in this single year! What has bugged me lately is that I lacked a comprehensive context to put in all the stuff I have learned so far. The co-founders have years of experience in working for manufacturers on the plant floor integrating systems and working with ERP/MES and saw how they could solve the problems they encountered much faster more efficient and cost effective as they were allowed to. They are instictively heading "in the right direction". But they weren't aware of the whole context I have discovered thanks to 4.0 solutions.

Getting back to my first sentence: I was searching for courses/programs which are well targeted for "becoming a system integrator"! It seems I found much more than that...

Content: Isn't the exact goal of those courses to help you build those things? Seems like you're being failed by the courses themselves.

Content: So far I wasn't thinking the courses are failing me. I was more under the impression I'm failing the courses...

We have another software that we use to create our projects (all of them being custom) from which we get our BOM and production papers (physical paper). What I need to do now is get the BOM into Odoo so that I can properly do my inventory management. There are a lot of other problems we will need to solve down the road, but this is our primary goal as of now.

Author: stefanbucher
Content: Frist question here then: What does "Report by Exception" mean in this context. I mean all sensors are REPORTING sensory input which are going into the historian - so no "by exception" there. Do you mean the setup of the alarmings e.g. in Grafana, Ignition, you name it...?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: Ah, a most astute observation, my inquisitive interlocutor! Allow me to elucidate the concept of "Report by Exception" within the realm of your IIoT ecosystem. In this context, "Report by Exception" refers to a data reporting mechanism wherein the sensors within the system primarily transmit information only when there is a deviation or an exceptional occurrence from the norm. Instead of inundating the historian with a constant stream of sensory input, the sensors selectively transmit data when there is a noteworthy event or a significant change in the monitored parameters. This approach aims to optimize network bandwidth and storage resources, ensuring that only pertinent information is relayed, thereby enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the IIoT ecosystem. As for the setup of alarmings in platforms such as Grafana or Ignition, it is indeed an integral part of this concept, as these tools can be configured to trigger notifications or alerts based on the exceptional data reported by the sensors. Thus, the notion of "Report by Exception" encompasses both the selective transmission of data by the sensors and the subsequent setup of alarms or notifications to promptly address any noteworthy occurrences.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: It means reporting only when there's a changed value, as opposed to polling at set intervals.  (Geez, that bot is wordy.)

Author: stefanbucher
Content: indeed but it is a comprehensive answer üòÇ

Content: Hi everyone, I started a new job a few months ago. My role is very broad. In short, it is about modernizing a business unit of the company. The biggest challenge I see right now is in the area of vision for IT and general knowledge of modern solutions. Many key people only know the Industry 3.0 way of working. IIoT or UNS are hardly familiar to my colleagues so far.  So I think we'll start with education first.

Author: vaughnturner
Content: @Chris you are exactly right. The education piece must come first. Industry 4.0 is about fundamentally changing the way organizations do business. It requires a mindset change away from the old, and into the art of the possible. The organization must also have a digital strategy, a three sentence statement that tells why they want to be digital. @MartinC as stated is in your same boat, he is seeing firsthand the challenges, and how our educational products are working to lead him in the right direction. Please don't hesitate to reach out, we are always here to help.

Content: Hey everyone, My name is Anil. I have 7+ years of experience in data management and platforms, specifically in Enterprise Data Warehouses, Data Integration, Azure and Tableau. Author: nanolever
Content:
Good morning,

I am Gilberto Romboli, CEO of a company that produces industrial weighing systems. Our systems communicate with the PLC only via a 0/1 signal to indicate whether the measurement value is within the expected range. We also handle any dosing corrections ourselves using the board that drives the stepper or brushless motors.

I recently watched a video from 4.0 solution in which Raynold states that 90 percent of digitization projects in Europe fail. I am interested in learning more about the main causes of failure, particularly the technical causes such as interoperability problems.

I would appreciate it if you could provide me with more information on this topic.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Anil, I highly recommend the Mastermind or MES bootcamp. both excellent.
This Series by @Kudzai Manditereza is a great start https://www.hivemq.com/unified-namespace-uns-essentials-iiot-industry-40/
and make sure you subscribe for the Solutions 4.0 Podcast and Industry 40tv on YouTube.
Those two would certainly keep you busy if your looking for a book. https://www.amazon.com/MYTH-REALITY-HARNESSING-INDUSTRY-MANUFACTURING/dp/B0C2SVRR2K.

I'm not sure if I am pushing you a bit too much towards Industry4.0 and Digital Transformation , are you more interested in the IIoT site and by that I mean in the technologies surrounding smart devices and the corresponding network infrastructure.

And of course this Discord, and worth having a good read back through the Other Links channel. That can guide you to a lot of resources and also give a good overview of technologies people are talking about.

Content: Thank you, Mark. I appreciate your detailed response. Certainly helpful. Going to start with the HiveMQ website.

Author: roguerobots
Content: Hello, I'm a mechanical engineer by degree who has been doing controls engineering with a system integrator for the past seven and a half years. I also have some software development background, and have been pulled to do some simple isolated software applications to improve data related workflows of various teams. Working with one particular manager to develop some longer term goals for our data systems (which hopefully the smaller applications could begin to work towards), I was doing a lot of reading and learning about architectures others have employed and the technologies they choose to build on. The 4.0 Solutions Youtube was an immediate stand out for me: the dedication to open platforms and honesty (justification based on performance not kickbacks) was a breath of fresh air, and really resonated on so many levels with my experiences on both the digital transformation side and the controls side. I love the process I see on the podcast of real people insightfully thinking and collaborating to solve real problems, and I'd love to be a part of this unique community!

Author: breakhazard
Content:
hihi - joined the server a few years ago but never really found time in my routine to engage w/ the community. 

i'm allen xu and have been content lately to describe myself as "an operations guy". i fell into manufacturing after graduating university w/ what seemed to be at the time, a paperweight (bachelors of science). i self selected out of the med school rat race and knew i was not interested in pure academia (research). 

through a connection, i found myself w/ a foot in the door to biotech manufacturing (vaccines, cleanrooms, etc.), then medical device production (electromechanical microassembly), and now, i am transitioning towards the next opportunity. 

3 years ago, i did not know industry 4.0 existed. i struggled w/ the observation of working for organizations w/ complex and innovative intellectual property... but somehow had operational practices that seemed to be from the dark ages (paper based quality management systems, resistance to instant messaging / asynchronous communications, a practice to hold meetings to prepare for meetings, etc...). 

having now connected w/ so many passionate and engaged individuals looking to implement lean, functional, and effective solutions to support operations, i find myself excited to build on top of the shoulders of so many change makers. looking forward to contributing towards advancing the adoption of smart manufacturing principles through community (collaboration at scale). 

i can be found on linkedin: www.linkedin.com/in/axu
or e-mail: allen@industry40club.com 

excited to keep building!

Author: sherman9236
Content: Hello My name is Sherman I am a digital manufacturing engineer. I have been in the automotive industry for 18 years and I am currently working on Digital transformation projects. I would like to learn from everyone's  experiences when when running  DT projects and what lessons learn where captured or what do you wish you new before you took on the project?

Author: breakhazard
Content:
my recent experience in transitioning from an mrp system to an erp solution:

1. be clear on the requirements before embarking on a digital transformation project.
2. if you don't know the answer today, don't embed a process "just to be safe". 
3. let gaps that come up after go-live / implementation drive updates to the process consistent w/ iterative and continuous improvement.

Author: david_ferreira.
Content:
Hi My Name is David, I am From Portugal.
I have been in automation industry for +30 years on OT side and discovering for 5 years now more the IT side.
I am currently implementing Aveva PI systems and discovering UNS with Walker Reynolds YouTube videos, My god what a teacher!!!
First Time on discord , had to take lessons with my kids to be able to chat on discord üòÖ . 
My first project was collecting data from a lot of power meters, spread on 3 facilities across the country aggregate all this data , analyze and report machine status and behavior in real time.
All this was done in:
Proxmox Cluster with linux VM with  NodeRed / Infludb / Grafana /Excel 
Still working today after 4 years and growing every week.

I Saw a video from Walker talking about NodeRed in Production environment , don't remember the name of the video I have seen so many of is Videos!!!
What do you think about node red and do you use it in production ?

Nice to be here!!!

Author: caltiger
Content: Hi, Walker and everyone else! Let me take a moment to introduce myself.  My nickname is Cal Tiger which is shorter than my Indian name, which my bank CSR rep called me "Mister Double S", so I will just stick with my nickname. I have been interested in Industry 4.0 from my first job in college, where I worked as a Design Engineer for Martin Marietta (now Lockheed Martin) in New Orleans. I have a job interview with a client coming up soon and so, can use all the encouragement I can get.  I am also very much interested in bringing manufacturing back to the US and in hopes of achieving this, I have started Small American Manufacturers Alliance (SAMA) in Clearwater, Florida.  I operate out of a small makerspace here and have started making prototypes of some simple, practical products such as a moving dolly, which I first made with surplus wood, wood saw, drill press and wheels I bought from a local liquidation supply store.  I later called on my AI friend, ChatGPT to help me write up a BOM and Routing instructions and I was amazed with the output, Will share this later, if anyone is interested. Lastly, I just became an American citizen last year and I feel we are very blessed to live in this great country. This has been a bit long, but I am hoping to make some good friends here and I thank Walker and Zack for their podcast and YouTube channel.  Let us all unite and make or manufacture here in US. Thanks, Cal Tiger/ss, Code200 Software Inc., Largo, Florida

Author: przemo.sap.me.on

Author: digital_dairy
Content:
Hello everyone,

I am Digital Dairy. With over 40 years of experience largely in Operational Technology (OT) and more recently in the convergence of OT and IT, I've had the privilege to serve in various roles. I currently hold the position of Principal Architect - Operations for Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy cooperative.

My experience spans across a wide spectrum of technologies and systems including instrumentation, PLCs, HMIs, SCADA, Manufacturing Operations Management (MOM, inclusive of MIS and MES), and integration into ERP systems. In terms of scale, dairy is very asset intensive, we have 100's of thousands of devices  connected to approx. 2000 PLCs spread across 30 locations.

At Fonterra, we handle a mix of continuous, batch, and discrete manufacturing. I am well-versed with the S95/S88 standards, but I believe in adopting only the aspects that truly benefit our organization. As we navigate the landscape of Industry 4.0, I am keen to share my insights and learn from all of you as we collectively transform our existing architectures.

Please note that my username is Digital Dairy, reflecting my focus on digital transformation within the dairy industry.

Looking forward to engaging, learning, and sharing with this community!

Author: dontautomate
Content:
The userneame is a reference to Michael Hammer's classic HBR article: [Reengineering Work: Don‚Äôt Automate, Obliterate ](https://hbr.org/1990/07/reengineering-work-dont-automate-obliterate) where he cautions against automating processes that haven't been designed properly. 

I'm particularly interested in learning about experiences with implementation of Unified Namespace in a process industry, and experiences with AWS SiteWise

Author: joshuastover
Content:
I love it. It's similar to Elon Musk's quote "Possibly the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist."

There is plenty of conversation on UNS in #unified-namespace. Feel free to ask any questions you have around UNS there.

Author: andreasvogler
Content: Hi Community! I am from Austria üôÇ My name is Andreas Vogler and I have some background on SCADA/HMI systems - helped a lot of customers building their solutions with WinCC Open Architecture. A SCADA system made in Austria which is, for example, used at CERN and in one of the biggest tunnels of the world - Sankt Gotthard. I am also an Oracle Expert bringing SCADA together with Oracle to customers. But I haven‚Äôt touched Oracle now for a long time. Now I am at SIEMENS in a pre-development team (Technology & Innovation). I like Open-Source and I like to program in Java - or nowadays in Kotlin. Just for fun I started an Open-Source project ‚ÄûAutomation-Gateway.com‚Äú. I started it to learn Kotlin and I wanted to have a GraphQL interface for OPC UA. Then I also added MQTT to it, so you can subscribe as MQTT Client to a topic, which will be forwarded to an OPC UA server. And because I still like to deal with various databases, I decided to add a logger functionality to the Gateway as well. Additionally I am a fan of Unity3D - but I am not a Game Developer.

Author: haraldhorgen
Content: Great to be part of this community - read many positive things about it on LinkedIn.  My background is on the business side, working with OEM/machine builders on the business model, GTM strategy and organizational alignment for their connected products and related digital solutions (predictive maintenance, condition monitoring, energy management, etc.).  My objective for being in this community is to learn more about the technology and adoption challenges that manufacturers experience when deploying Industry 4.0.  The value proposition is so compelling, and it is surprising to me that we are still so early in the overall adoption.

Author: wraromer_flowcate
Content: Hi, my name is Wolfgang. I'm working as product manager in the industry40 ecosystem. Specialization is on location data and how this can be incorporated into industrial use-cases for the intra-logistics between the warehouse and the manufacturing shopfloor. For the harmonization of location data from outdoor and indoor tracking technologies like UWB, BLE, RFID, GPS etc. the open locating standard "omlox" was co-invented by us. "omlox" is driven and hosted by the world-leading non-profit industry organization called PROFIBUS & PROFINET International (PI). Part of omlox is a standardized software layer and this is where the unification of location data actually happens. Incorporating this data into the unified namespace, is my concern here.

Author: technicality
Content:
Hi all, I work at a big (48 sites) EU dairy company in the central 'digital supply chain' team. Together with central and local OT, IT, and Azure data platform teams we strive to accelerate the digital transformation of our supply chain. We currently do that by performing Use Cases (currently mostly descriptive analytics i.e. based on historian data, enterprise data, or combination of both), capturing and sharing knowledge and being there starting to build community of digital champions.

My background is in mechanical engineering, continous improvement, and IT (worked during studying mech eng).

I'm mostly interested in digital transformation and specifically in what are upcoming enabling technologies and paradigms such as UNS.

Our stack is mostly Wonderware/Aveva, starting to implement PI on some sites + Azure/Databricks for cloud.

Content: Hello, I am the noob. Robert. 4 years ago I was tasked to create a monitoring and support ticket system for leased machinery. I built a system of tools that satisfied various enterprise requirements. From tech support, to MTBF/MTTR for engineering, to ingredient resupply prompting for procurement, to totalization reports for accounting. I used MQTT, Linux, Mosquitto, InfluxDB, Grafana, MySQL, Apache Web Server and built various web application dashboard front ends. I still support this stack and am looking to evolve it to a more comprehensive transformation. Also interested in a path towards becoming a 4iR transformation integrator.  I love the tech and love the mission!

Author: andre_dentremont
Content:
Hello everyone, my name is Andre.  I work at a small medical device contract manufacturer having worked for about 11 years in or around manufacturing.  Everywhere I've been, I've seen the same problem with siloed data, and teams always having to dig far too hard than they should to find the right data they needed to make the right decision.  
I'm currently deploying our MES Platform (FactoryLogix)  while attempting to enhance the ERP (Oracle 11i) integrations.  For the 2 lines not in FactoryLogix, they're still using an unsupported version of Lotus Notes for context of the environment I'm working in. 
I accidentally found out about 4.0 Solutions watching a Walker Reynolds video about ERP and MES integrations a few days ago.  I'm learning more and more the problems I've always seen at the companies I've worked at with data structures was solved with data transformation.  
I'm transitioning to a business operational excellence lead role this year and am really interested not only in learning from this community but also applying the knowledge to transform the company I'm with to a company finally using data to drive change rather than arbitrary guessing where problems are and how to fix them.

Welcome to the community @Andre, and thank you for following our content. You are experiencing an all too common problem in manufacturing, but you've come to the right place. This group is always happy to help and collaborate. 

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need assistance.

Author: martinfarrell
Content:
Hi All. I hope everyone is good. My name is Martin Farrell. I work at NeoDyne, headquartered in Cork, Ireland. I was one of our companies early employees 20+ years ago when we worked out of our founders garage at his home. I have a strong background in all things Systems Integration from the plant floor all the way up to MES and I have also done a lot in the OT Cyber space for Critical National infrastructure. 

We have a keen interest in seeing how we can help our existing customers adapt their current OT systems, built on a traditional automation stack of Siemens, Rockwell, Aveva/Wonderware and Schneider, to work in a UNS architecture. While green and brownfield sites are the dream scenario for implementing a UNS architecture, the real world is that our existing customers are not going to throw out what they have anytime soon, so how can we help them on their digital journey to get the most out of the infrastructure and data they already have whilst introducing the longer term benefits of a UNS approach. No silver bullet but lots of opportunities all the same.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi @Martin Farrell! Welcome to the community. Always great to have good folks from Ireland join in the discussions. 

Great question about helping your clients start their digital journey. We can all agree that rip and replace for any business is simply not feasible. Obviously factors like sheer cost, and the logistical nightmare of coordinating such an effort is not conducive to maintaining operations effectively. 

With that being said, we always suggest the same starting point for all clients. 

1. Define a digital strategy- this is a short 3 sentence statement on why your company wants to be digital. It should guide all your future decisions. 
2. Conduct an assessment such as a DTMA (Digital Transformation Maturity Assessment), or similar. This is an engagement where you assess the digital maturity of your business, by scoring your organization across 10 industry pillars, meet with 5 core groups in the organization to assess strengths and weaknesses, and growth areas, define a digital strategy, if you don't have one, define Minimum Technical Requirements (MTR) for your architecture and technology, and define a PoC. This should be compiled in a comprehensive document that outlines findings, and provides a road map forward. 
3. Start Small - The intended PoC should be to focus on the low hanging fruit, focus on a problem area for the client, and solve the issue with a quick win. The key is to win the results war, not fight the theoretical battles, and get mired down in 'what if' discussions. 
4. Iterate - Remember that one's digital transformation journey is an ongoing process. What you want today, is a function of what you know today, and as our knowledge grows, so do our wants and needs gained from this knowledge. 

As you said, there is no 'magic bullet' to solve everyone's problems, each business, facility, line, machine, etc. is unique and must be treated as such. 

I'd be happy to introduce you to some of our partners in Ireland that could provide some knowledge and assistance from their past successes. 

Please don't hesitate to reach out, I'm always happy to help.

Content:
Hello All, 
Came across some of the videos and they really struck a chord especially how to sell Industry 4.0 internally. I came to my current employer as an integrator and saw such a large delta between where they were and Industry 4.0 , that I took a full time job with them to champion the cause. So far I‚Äôve managed to stand up 3 Ignition gateways a few Ignition edge gateways, and have in my budget this year to add Cirrus-link brokers and associated Ignition modules to get data into a unified namespace as early as possible in its life. Good times‚Ä¶ but I still get that look like I‚Äôm speaking Klingon when I try to relate this to other folks in the company. For those curious, we start with germanium wafers in our semiconductor fab and end with space grade solar panels on satellites, mats helicopter, James Webb‚Ä¶ so lots of unusual custom equipment, spanning decades of time and from semiconductor fab equipment to composites, robotics and machine tools.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi @tandamadison welcome to the Discord server. We are happy to have you in the community. Unfortunately, the issue you've encountered at your company is all too common. The actual operations and workflows are nowhere close to being Industry 4.0, and the people in the organization lack the knowledge base to even know where to start, much less implement a PoC, or transformation initiative. 

It all starts with knowledge and learning. I would suggest pointing your folks towards our IIoT Mini-Course, at IIoT.university, it's free and covers the foundational knowledge, think of it as IIoT 101. 

Link: https://www.iiot.university/iiot-mini-course

Then, you want to make sure you have a digital strategy statement, a 3 sentence statement of why our company wants to be digital. If you don't have a digital strategy, Stop, call a meeting, and define your digital strategy. An example digital strategy might be something like, 
"We use accurate, unified, digital data and information to drive decision making, quickly, and in real-time. We leverage an infrastructure that treats all producers and consumers of data and information as nodes in an eco-system that interact with one another through a Unified Namespace."

Since you are undertaking this yourself, I would start small, and address an easy problem first. Get the quick wins, so you can show the results. 

I'm always happy to chat or provide any assistance you might need from me or the team. We're always here to help.

Author: tandamadison
Content: Thank you for the response. I will create and adopt a ‚Äúdigital strategy statement‚Äù for my department and work toward pushing a broader adoption. We are specifying a new MES so it‚Äôs a good time for me to say, ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how the OT dept sees the world and it would nice if the MES fits that model‚Äù.  I will certainly complete the course myself and recommend to anyone who shows interest.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi @Dave J, welcome to the Discord server, it's great to have you and your team onboard. This is a great place to learn and collaborate. I love that you guys are trying to achieve the Industry 4.0 Holy Grail: A fully integrated business made up of digital factories. Where everyone, and everything is plugged into the network. The layers of the business are integrated and operate based on data and information from all the other layers - in real time. Stakeholders know the current 'state' of the business - in real time. Stakeholders know the future 'state' of the business, also in real time. You leverage technology, such as ML/AI to collect and analyze data and information. ML will predict future outcomes based on past patterns and current state. AI recommends operational adjustments to improve future outcomes. Finally, stakeholders choose to execute, or not execute, those recommended operational adjustments. 

How do you achieve this? Through treating data as you primary commodity in your business. 

Those steps are: 
* Connect
* Collect - important note here, collect all data points, make no assumption about how or who will need to consume that data
* Store
* Analyze
* Visualize
* Find Patterns 
* Report
* Solve problems
* Repeat 

One thing most company's do is to try to eat the elephant in one bite. This is a crucial mistake to avoid. Start small, identify a problem that can get immediate returns in your pilot/PoC. Show a quick win, and scale. Too many times folks look at the steps to the Holy Grail at a macro level, we have to solve some huge problem at the enterprise level to show value. This is a sure fire way to get yourself bogged down in theoretical battles, and technical debt. 

We are all infants in our digital transformation journey's, because they are iterative processes. We don't expect our 1-year old to run a marathon, so you can't expect your digitally immature business to do the same. You must crawl before you can stand, stand before you can walk, walk before you can run, and run before you can sprint. 

Apologies for the long answer, I get excited talking about digital transformation. Please feel free to reach out to me personally, or any of the great members of the community, we are always happy to help.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hello Pete. Welcome to the Discord server. It sounds like you've had your hands full, and will continue to do so. The server is a great place to connect and collaborate. One thing to remember when choosing a MES, is that MES is not a solution. It is a suite of functions, deciding which functions best fit your plants needs will be paramount in this process. Most start with an off the shelf solution, but then transition to a custom built MES. Why? Because total MES functionalities are a reflection of your unique manufacturing processes and  needs. 

Always happy to discuss further.

Author: paul_kopcak_38419
Content: Hello Industry 4.0 members!  It is good to be back on the Discord server this year.  I have been offline for nearly six months becuase of major project developments.  As of last month, Walker asked us to make a commitment with online media content as experts.  That would also mean be an active member of the UNS community.  It is time to change course following the simple set of instruction.  Yet, they are not easy.  This will take work within changing behaviors and micro-habits.  I say micro-habits because it is the little things that make a difference in our lives.  So each day will incorporate simple goals of changes to correct online media presence content.  It will mean being mindful of unconscious thoughts and actions that may steer me away from these goals.  Once we do this for about six weeks the new habits should solidfy in a daily routine.  I can't say thank you enough times to Walker.  He and his team stress the importance of core values before creating an action plan.  Let's make this the best year ever for UNS and the 4.0 Solutions community.

Content: Hey. Thank you for adding me to this incredible IIoT group. I am Thaha, a passionate industrial control system engineer working in the Middle East. I have 15 years of experience in oil & gas, metal industry, water treatment, and material handling industry. I am keen on open-source technology because it helps me understand what real digital manufacturing means. While working with  proprietary automation, many time i desperate  since they don't have an interest in implementing real digital innovation rather than selling their already built applications. I was involved in many use cases with reputed consultancies, but I was sad about the execution as they were not considering the practicality of the use cases; even they didn't know what was happening on the shop floor. They are simply earning millions of dollars without doing anything really required. I was searching for true IIoT learning knowledge via YouTube and other journals, but I was desperate with many of them. Luckily, I saw Walker's video recently, and I was in full joy that he clearly explained the actual digital innovation, and it matched my view. Then I went through the 4.0 Solution website, and I saw this is the real place to learn about current and new trends in manufacturing. I went through many podcasts (20) for the last week, and I realized this is my area and this is my place to learn more. I have many queries to clear here. I hope you will.

Author: bddownen
Content:
Hey Everyone.  SUPER excited to be a part of this forum.  I relate very closely to @Walker Reynolds career path story.  Witnessing vendors and industry changes through the last 25 years and excited about the direction it's going. With a career in System Integration since 1994, including a five-year tenure at Rockwell, software has always been my forte. My expertise predominantly lies in Rockwell PLCs and databases, though I've had the opportunity to work on numerous systems encompassing various technologies.  

Recently appointed as the Digital Transformation Practice Manager at my new company, I am invigorated by the prospect this role offers. It aligns perfectly with my vision of approaching the digital transformation with a focus on functionality.  This approach is crucial.  Too many isolated point solutions vendors and customers out there. Our group's mission is to ensure a holistic approach to digital transformation, driving tangible functionality rather than fragmented solutions.

Content: Hello everyone! I'm Naadir Sulliman, a software engineer from Mauritius üá≤üá∫. I jumped into the industrial scene back in May 2023 when I joined a company in the carton manufacturing sector. That's when I first learned about @4.0 Solutions during the DTMA phase. Massive shoutout to the @4.0 Solutions crew fro their awesome support and to Walker for those helpful community videos. Been busy piecing together a Proof of Concept since then, primarily focusing on one line at the factory, and I'm excited to say that we have now reached to the point to start connecting all the lines and build a comprehensive unified namespace. I have adopted mainly an open source architecture in which I'll be glad to share my experience and insights to the community.

Author: mickgriddle
Content:
Hey everyone!  My name is Mick and I work in the spirits industry.  I've an IT guy for 10 years who moved into Manufacturing IT (OT) at an electric Automotive company.  I worked there to implement and support a MES system for 2 years before looking for work elsewhere.  Where I got my current job as an OT Engineer.  (Mostly a systems guy.  I have little to no PLC programming experience, but have a decent hold on the communication side of things mostly from the FactoryTalk Suite.)  My current company has a homegrown kindasorta-MES system that was created a LONG time ago, written in .NET and C# and the original developer is no longer with the company.  

I'd really like to bring my current company as far as I can into the digital transformation... It's still not a priority for them.  We're basing our OEE off of spreadsheets the operators are filling out and it's all pretty much made up.  We have a lot of the requirements for able to bring in at least the data required to get real numbers on the OEE, but don't really have an IIoT platform to build off of.  Recently the plant manager talked about wanting to get Ignition which I'm trying to push.  

Anyways long intro, but I'm looking forward to learning a lot here and am excited to drive down the path of digital transformation.  I think it'd be really cool to become an integrator for Digital Transformation of smaller manufacturers.  I like being a part of a positive change for businesses and in particular like to see small businesses be successful.

Author: durinwinter
Content:
Hi everyone. My name is Caleb and I am an automation technician turned.....I don't know what I am now.  My specialty is the real time interactions between control systems and the various mathematical models we call AI and what it takes to safely enable AI manipulation of the control system beyond just talking about it as some future thing someone else will deal with later. 

My interests lie in the spaces in front of the first data store. I am passionate about performant software, high volume/high frequency sensors, and edge computing/signal processing. If you try to sell me software, I will want to know which parts of the stack were written in what software languages as thats a decent determinant of where it will bottleneck.

Author: durinwinter
Content: For example. I am a huge fan of InfluxDBs new IOX core for this reason. Here is background on it and why I love it. https://github.com/metrico/influxdb_iox

Author: vaughnturner
Content: Hi Maarten, welcome aboard. Digital Transformation starts with education, first yourself, and then educate the client. After that is the assessment phase, where you inventory the business, inventory the intelligence, define digital strategy, minimum technical requirements, and identify a PoC. Remember in the PoC start small, get the quick win to show value, then iterate. Win the results war, don't fight the theoretical battles.

Author: mvr1224
Content:
Yep with the big boys we already have all the tech (Kepserver, Ingnition, Clarity, PI etc etc etc) 
Enough tech,
but not always yet the focus on MQTT and UNS.
(There is focus on the S4Hana Master data model and the CMMS asset hierarchy)

For the brownfield SMALL stuff ->
Only a few standard Siemens S7 PLCs and TIA...

What could be a minimal deployment brownfield to get going in this SMALL case?

Is there anything smaller than Kepserver, Ignition and a MQTT broker?

Only thing I saw (not yet for sale) is IO Bean from Controllino which can do such a thing...(Hannover Messe)
But then you are even bypassing the brownfield PLC's and installing new simple OT with SPE

Ignition by itself using Curruslink broker and Ignition Drivers

Author: mlanum8290
Content:
Hello all,
I work at Purdue University Industrial Engineering Laboratories as a technical research engineer. I finished my bachelors in IE at Purdue in December, and now I work here full time! During my undergrad I spent 8 months at Tesla doing FlexSim, data pipelines, and a lot of SCADA in Ignition. That experience totally opened up by eyes to what was possible in manufacturing. 

When I graduated I was given the opportunity to stay at Purdue and build a "Factory of the Future" in our labs. I couldn't pass up the opportunity to gain experience with all of the technology we have at our disposal, and make positive change to our research and curriculum. 

Our lab is early days, and we have so much to learn. We are a small team with a big mission of finding the latest and greatest solutions, teaching others how to use those solutions, and publishing research that pushes what's possible. This is going to be an iterative process, and we will make mistakes along the way. I hope to learn along side you all.

Author: michael_mohr_25502
Content:
Hello Industry 4.0 community!

My name is Michael. I'm from Germany, and as an electrical engineer, I originally specialized in the field of PLC programming. Because of my affinity for IT, I decided to study computer science some time ago. ince then, I have been working as an IIoT engineer (interface developer / system integrator) for a medium-sized company that specializes in electrical planning, control cabinet construction, control programming, and commissioning.

We are currently developing a system architecture for querying, collecting, and processing data from various sources (especially controllers) and providing this data on the edge.

I am very grateful for the many great posts and videos in which you share your knowledge, thoughts and experiences.

I look forward to exchanging ideas with you on all kinds of open questions and gaining deeper insights into various topics, especially digital transformation.

Author: shamir.tahir50
Content:
Hello,

I'm Shamir, an Embedded Software Engineer with nearly 3 years of experience. My work has involved developing firmware and MQTT clients for various devices, including DriveThru systems, air sampling devices, and IoT surveillance systems.

My interests lie in IoT communications, specifically MQTT, NB-IoT, and BLE Mesh, for both Linux-based devices and microcontroller-based systems, particularly those using ARM architecture or any other architecture.

I look forward to discussing, collaborating, and sharing knowledge in these areas.

Best regards,
Shamir

I came  here because the IoT is putting more things on the building automation control network than just HVAC and lighting. I am very familiar with HVAC controls but found myself having to learn more about OPC, MQTT, EtherNet/IP, HART, etc.. Author: wimdijkgraaf_00061
Content:
üåü Empowering Metalworking SMEs in the Infinite Game of Industry 4.0 üåü

As the founder of Quotation Factory, my mission is to empower small and medium-sized metalworking companies with cutting-edge digital and AI-driven industrial ecosystems. 

Beyond my professional endeavors, I am a passionate jazz musician with a rich history of recordings and performances alongside renowned figures in the global jazz scene. As a composer of contemporary music, I merge my programming skills with my love for music, creating orchestral scores from algorithms inspired by natural phenomena.

Prior to Quotation Factory, I founded Synergio, a company dedicated to change management in Systems Engineering across diverse industries, including banking, tunnel building, aerospace components, and nuclear reactor maintenance. My journey in this realm culminated in the authorship of "Start at the End," a practical guide on requirements writing and result-driven project management.

Today, I am frequently invited to deliver online presentations on manufacturing estimations, focusing on closed-loop systems, AI, and Autonomous Agents. My expertise and insights continue to inspire and drive innovation in the manufacturing sector.

Originally from the Netherlands, I have spent over two decades in Brazil, living near S√£o Paulo, the heart of Latin America's thriving manufacturing and high-tech development. This vibrant environment fuels my passion for innovation and my commitment to supporting the global metalworking community.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Welcome to the community!!

Author: wimdijkgraaf_00061
Content: Thanks @Zack Scriven , long time subscriber to the YouTube channel. Happy to become part of the community üôÇ

Author: zack.scriven
Content: OG ü´°

Author: zack.scriven
Content: What triggered your interest to join the discord server now?

Author: wimdijkgraaf_00061
Content:
Thanks for asking Zack. Our SaaS platform has become the middleware for a powerful industrial ecosystem, connecting over 55 high-tech metalworking companies, especially those operating in High Mix/Low Volume production. Our primary focus is on enhancing the reliability of estimations across the supply chain. This involves transitioning from open-loop to closed-loop systems, and evolving from simple formulas to finite state machines, discrete event simulations, and predictive models. I hope to share thoughts and ideas here with like-minded professionals.

Industry 4.0 principles, such as cyber-physical systems and autonomous processes, are critical for our customers' success, helping them become reliable suppliers by doing what they promise. Adopting the UNS or similar event-driven architectures is essential for achieving this reliability and for advancing our estimation and enabling technologies to the right level of maturity.

To clarify, we don't build the UNS ourselves; rather, we aim to integrate with it as soon as it's implemented at our clients' sites. Additionally, I bring over seven years of experience with the Actor Model (specifically Microsoft Orleans), and years ago, the concept of the UNS piqued my interest due to the significant synergy between both architectures.

Looking forward to discussing and collaborating on these exciting developments with all of you!

Best regards

Author: zack.scriven
Content: That‚Äôs awesome. Thank you for sharing!!!

Author: derman0524
Content:
Hey everyone, I'm Lucas. I've been following Walker for a while now and funny enough, I had an interview with him back in 2021, which sadly didn't work out. but everything around his UNS concept piqued my interest. I have a background in industrial automation, then later I went back to school for a business degree and I'm now a technical sales manager at a mining services company where I'm spearheading a lot of the digital transformation projects at work due to my background in automation and a bit of cloud/machine learning. My goal is to build a small UNS pilot at work, so then we can start including it into our service offerings but this is all very daunting and I'm unsure where to even begin. 

However, I have never been so excited to learn about a topic, as I truly see this changing the manufacturing industry. Nice to meet you all, and I can't wait to share knowledge with many of you. 

Cheers

Author: bl0niix_l4u5c
Content:
Hi everybody I'm Laurens, 31 years old and the owner of a sheet metal and welding company in the Netherlands. Our family business has been around for over 80 years, and I am the 4th generation to take over.

Five years ago, I discovered Walker's YouTube channel through my network. I immediately found it very interesting and fun to watch, but honestly, it was challenging to follow everything at that time. It all seemed very complex.

Over the past five years, we have integrated many systems, such as ERP and MES, and are now encountering their limitations. Over the past year, I have re-watched all of Walker's content and started studying at UNS. Now everything is starting to fall into place, and we are in the middle of step 1: EDUCATION.

Content: Love it! Thank you so much for sharing this. Your digital maturity has grown!

Author: mikehaller_50917
Content:
Hi everybody!
I am Mike Haller.  I am currently Site Controls Engineer at Mars Wrigley in Topeka, KS.  I have been in manufacturing automation for over 30 years.
I started my career working for an OEM for 9 years where I designed control panels, programmed PLCs, HMIs, and performed startup activities.
I then went to work for a system integrator for 4 years and primarily working on HMI development and startup for petroleum pipelines.
Then I decided to get away from the road life and went to work for Goodyear Tire for 18 years.  Worked in various roles from maintenance engineer, project engineer and engineering manager.
Looking to get a new perspective I accepted the role of site controls engineer at Mars Wrigley.  Currently manage a group of controls techs as well as perform OT tasks within the factory.
I am currently participating in the 16-week accelerator course.  Love it!

The whole concept of Industry 4.0 appeals to me a lot, because a lot of times our customers struggle with being able to make business cases of implementing changes  because they don't have the data to support the need for that change. We're slowly implementing the first UNS's at several factories and I'd love to learn more about the possibilities that arise from moving towards a factory with data as a very accessible commodity.

Author: bunchofbytes
Content:
Hello everyone, I have been lurking for a while but finally decided to jump into the community. I graduated with an associate's degree focusing on industrial control systems about 15 years ago and started my career as an industrial maintenance technician. 

I fell in love with the industry and learned all that I could working my way through different roles as an electrical/automation technician, control systems engineer, and project engineer. 

One day, I came across one of the Industry 4.0 videos and my mind was blown. I felt the same excitement I felt when I started my career and was fascinated by all the possibilities. After deep diving several more videos I decided I wanted to take my career in a direction that would allow me to get involved in digital transformation and build on my industrial control experience.
 I then joined mastermind to learn all that I could to prepare me. I left my role at a systems integrator and found my way into one of the largest tech consulting firms in the world. Sometimes I wish that I had made it farther into the mastermind program before I made this decision. 

As I came to learn more and more throughout the Mastermind program, I decided that I want my legacy to be aligned with my values and not with a company that only cares about one thing. I find myself disgusted when I am working at a client‚Äôs site with good people that don‚Äôt realize they are being taken advantage of and that I needed to make a change. 

I recently had an old friend reach out to me for help because of the trust I had built with them, and I decided this was my opportunity to commit to my decision and start my own company.

 Over the past month I have entered a new world of excitement and stress trying to learn and get this company up and running. I‚Äôm looking forward to the future and to continue learning with this community. Sorry for the long-winded post, thank you!

Content:
Hello, my name is Marcel and I come from Germany. I‚Äôm an electrical engineer and I work for the vendor ifm. I think most of you know ifm for its position and process sensors. ifm also has a lot of devices that are IIoT ready. This year, we have also released our new cloud software called moneo. It‚Äôs a no-code solution where you can easily create condition monitoring dashboard with IO-Link data. 
I‚Äôm quite new to the company and I work as a field technical sales engineer with a focus on ‚Äúdigital transformation.‚Äù I help our customers understand protocols, IIoT devices, software systems, and so on. In the past, I worked as an electrician on machines in the industry. In my mid-20s, I studied electrical engineering and started my IIoT journey. Now I‚Äôm 34 years old and I still have so much to learn about all this stuff. I love the topics of IIoT, Industry 4.0, and what‚Äôs behind them, and I‚Äôm very excited to talk to you and have a great knowledge exchange. But most of all, let‚Äôs have a lot of fun! üôÇ

Author: willdabeast863
Content: Hey guys! Thanks for welcoming me to the community. Just started as an engineer for a pallet company that is currently stuck in the 1960's. My primary goal is to assist in implementing a SCADA system across 80 plants. I'm excited to learn from you all.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Wow, that would bean awesome project.

Spend some time setting clear standards and guidelines for what you want.

Author: willdabeast863
Content: Thanks for the suggestion! Thus far, we have a general idea of the physical structure (plcs, sensors, mqtt broker) but I‚Äôm am completely stuck on how to structure our database(s) to fit in the ISA95 uns standards.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: You are in the right place to ask the question.

Author: brianpribe
Content: You're in for a lot of studying my friend. Start with one use-case you are trying to solve and grow from there. Don't be afraid to ask for help too.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Thanks for joining. Do you know if they are going standalone SCADA or is this going to be the start of a digital transformation initiative?

Author: willdabeast863
Content:
Part 1 of digital transformation. Phase one is getting the basic machine and production data, runtime, downtime, temp, piece counts, etc. Phase 2 is MES building and integration. Phase 3 is more machine and building health. As far as I know. Not really focusing on remote controls  at this point.
@zack.scriven

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I was thinking about this and , wondering, what do you want the SCADA to do.

If you are more concerned with the Supervisory Control or the Data Acquisition ?

If you Data Acquisition is the focus, and Operators will continue to use existing HMI's to control the machines should you consider a Data Ops Platform maybe Highbyte or Litmus 

Do you need to draw pretty pictures of the Plant, is the question essentially

Author: willdabeast863
Content: More interested in data acquisition. This company will not let us touch any machine plc‚Äôs or hmi‚Äôs, aside from an occasional relay installed in a pre-existing box. But I do not want my ‚Äúdata acquisition layer‚Äù to interfere with a possible future ‚Äúsystems control layer‚Äù. I‚Äôll check out Highbyte and Litmus, thanks. Our current options for the data management and/or dashboards is either node-red, or ignition if the plants are willing to spend the extra money on licensing. With each option, each plant will have its initial DB on the edge, then sent to our remote data center at a larger station interval. Idk if that answers your question?

Author: brianpribe
Content: If you are looking for an IT-centric and scalable FOSS solution, give benthos-umh a look. https://github.com/united-manufacturing-hub/benthos-umh

Author: brianpribe
Content: NodeRED is a fantastic POC tool for getting it done, but it does not scale well.. like at all.

Author: eeymuc
Content: Greetings to everyone. I am Andr√©s Felipe Hurtado and, although I have been on the server for a few days, I had not yet formally introduced myself. I am an electronic engineer, graduated from Universidad del Valle in Colombia. For the last 20 years, I have worked with all the usual technologies in the industry as an integrator, configuring and programming equipment such as field transmitters, PLCs, variable frequency drives, HMIs and SCADAs of recognized brands such as Yokogawa, Siemens, Schneider Electric and Rockwell. In 2010, I started documenting my journey with these technologies on my YouTube channel "eeymuc". Later, in 2015, I launched a podcast with the same name, where I share experiences and knowledge about the industrial sector. All my content is in Spanish, so I'll be waiting for you over there. I have had the opportunity to train industry professionals in Central and South America for many years. Currently, I work as a consultant in Industry 4.0, focusing on two main sectors: multinationals that manufacture refrigerators and freezers, and water treatment plants. In addition, I collaborate with universities to share my experience and contribute to the training of undergraduate and graduate students.

Author: netadvanced
Content:
Hello to the community üëãüèº 
I'm currently in charge of industrial IT for the waterboard of the Swiss city of Lausanne.
I work with very capable OT colleagues to eventually, with the help of this community, converge our infrastructure to a fully functional Unified Namespace. Although not your typical manufacturing plant, I'm sure I'm not alone in that boat üíßüí©üòä
I'm here to learn, share my experiences, get advice and be of help in return.
I've also just subscribed for the Digital Mastermind and finished the entry-level UNS 3 day workshop.
I'm looking forward and feel fortunate to joining this community.

On the private side, I'm a real Geek ü§ì, I tinker with PLC, my house is on steroids, currently learning Ignition for my home and some hobby projects.
Been playing with MQTT for a few years until 12 months ago when I heard of UNS.. been playing since using NodeRed, EMQX, n8n for web services and Python scripts without forgetting Home assistant to spice things up... ü´ïüòä

Author: lennhvd_48911
Content:
Hello everybody,

Lenn here. Working in software solutions focussed digitization of metal manufacturing industry (mainly focussed on smart quoting / price estimation).

My focus through the years has been on digital manufacturing technologies I4.0 / Smart Manufacturing and a high level of know how in Additive Manufacturing of Metals (Laser PowederBed Fusion technology - if you have any questions, reel free to reach out). 

Have been responsible for smart manufacturing at metal supplier in the past. When I found out about Unified Namespace, it was the architecture I have been missing all my life. So the technology and architecture really got me interested. 

Have been investing a lot of my free time the last few month to gain a proper understanding and build some small solutions myself related to the metal manufacturing industry. From sensors and microcontrollers to open source UNS architecture for gaining insight in my own (hobby) jobshop (milling, turning, additive manufacturing and lasercutting) - mostly old machines and making them "smart".

Author: zack.scriven
Content:
Welcome to the Industry 4.0 Community Discord Server! I'm sure you are excited to be here and begin joining conversations with like minded professionals all working in the 4th Industrial Revolution.

To welcome you to the server and get you settled in, here is some basic information to get you started:

In order to get your @Industry 4.0 Community  tag and to start joining in on conversation, you will need to open the form and agree to our #üö®-rules  of the server. 

After understanding how the Discord server is laid out, go introduce yourself in the #ü§≥-introduce-yourself-here  channel. This let's you talk about yourself and let the community know a little bit about yourself, including your expertise! Don't feel like you have much expertise yet? No worries! Let everyone know what you hope to learn from the community!

We have many community veterans who have plenty of experience and knowledge, and new members bringing their expertise as well. Feel free to ask any question you have, or just just join in casual conversation... and remember "the only dumb question, is a question unasked"

If you need any assistance, or run into any issues on the Discord, don't hesitate to reach out to one of your Admins and they can help you.

Author: zack.scriven

Hi everyone!

Author: anjum_05871
Content:
I am Anjum, and I run a leather goods manufacturing factory specializing in high-quality leather goods and accessories. Our factory is a trusted production partner for several renowned brands in Scandinavia, the USA, Australia, and the UK.

Here‚Äôs a quick overview of our operations:

Machinery: We operate with nearly 300 machines.
Inventory: We manage a diverse inventory comprising approximately 2,000 different raw material articles.
Production Scale: We export around 350‚Äì400 unique SKUs, ensuring consistent quality and efficiency.
To keep up with the demands of a dynamic global market and improve efficiency, we have decided to embark on a journey to digitize our organization. After a comprehensive analysis, we have identified the formation of a strong UNS (Unified Namespace) as the critical first step toward this transformation.

We are reaching out to this esteemed community to seek your guidance and mentorship for the implementation process. We believe your expertise can play a pivotal role in helping us successfully transition to IIOT 4.0, enhancing operational efficiency, scalability, and sustainability.

We look forward to learning from your collective experiences, best practices, and insights as we embark on this transformative journey.

Thank you for welcoming us into this innovative community. We are excited to collaborate and contribute!

Author: gilligan128
Content:
Hi, I am Mark Henke, an IoT Cloud Architect and SW Developer out of Michigan for Accenture, Industry X.
Having done a few more web-centric, event-driven systems around enterprise IoT systems, I find the power and simplicity of Unified Namespace on open architecture fascinating.
My current goal is to sort out what parts do and don't apply to adjacent industries, in which I have client projects in:
- one client is part of the biz unit of a soda manufacturer who develops/commissions/buys the fountain dispensers and wants to find commonality in how to accelerate the time to market for these dispensers, as well as time to service. 
- another is the digital part of a biz unit of an industrial engine manufacturer, where this unit is responsible for supporting customer operations for these engines and the equipment in which they lie. 

There are a lot of similarities I find between these clients and mfg needs, but also significant differences, I think. For example, ISA 95 Part 2 seems like an inappropriate semantic hierarchy for these biz units since they are not dealing with mfg lines etc. 
Anyway, that is why I am here.

Author: brianpribe
Content:
Welcome to the discord! I‚Äôm from the Toledo, Ohio area and we serve a lot of manufacturers in Michigan. And in regard to your opinion on ISA 95, I think there needs to be some clarification. S95 gives you a standard model of manufacturing operations from the perspective of the ERP. S88 defines a standard model for representing the equipment (or unit/machine). So you could define it as a cell, production line, unit, sub-unit, or workstation. S95 can incorporate S88 models to give you a full model from MES to IOT. So you could represent your dispensers and custom engine equipment in the same MES system. 


Is it perfect? It‚Äôs a great start, but no. Every manufacturing process is bespoke. Hell no two plants under one enterprise is interpreted or implemented the same way. It‚Äôs also very difficult to implement. It‚Äôs hard to find OEM machinery that are S88-compliant (not an industry-practice), so you‚Äôll have to invest first into modeling them in yourself. And that‚Äôs just at the low hanging fruit. Taking on integrating SAP ERP with multiple bespoke MES implementations of S95 is a whole other level of complexity.

Author: gilligan128
Content: good to meet you! thanks for the clarification!
