Author: scadamerc
Content:
Morning all - Im Sean, I've been on the discord in the past, but this is a new account. Ive got experience in all sorts of manufacturing and packaging, along with many projects in process control for O&G, Water, passenger trains. ect. I have a very strong background in UNIX and Linux - container admin is a speciality. I have a deep love for Node-Red  and I really think it is the future tool for I4.0 Engineering and IoT. I prefer javascript to python (especially py 2.9) any day of the week. I am a recovering addict - redeemed by the blood of Christ. 

had a blast at proveIt - really want to see @RickBullotta at the next one, and we (as an industry) should be pushing vendors to use version control. Would really love to see GitHub or GitLab attend next year 

Looking forward to joining the conversation!

Author: vyrlum
Content: Hello everyone. My name is Matt I presented with Portainer and Cedalo at the conference demonstrating the case study I developed for Seadrill.  I kept hearing about a community discord during my conversations at the conference and felt left out so here I am. My background is very multi-disciplinary ranging from core ISIT, Cybersecurity, Industrial power generation and distribution, Industrial controls & automation, ML/AI, reliability, embedded systems, and a general tech enthusiast in all regards.

Author: scadamerc
Content:
Hi Matt.. great to see you here, we talked a bit at the conference about how Seadrill's implementation is pretty close to NOV's approach. Loved your presentation, and enjoyed speaking with you, and Roger Light, and Portainer!!

Do you keep your container images - or config files under version control? I am just curious

Author: vyrlum
Content: Aside from the gh repos setup for the conference demo, the development has been a bit freeform. I have git repos setup for every section of the project scope for the purposes of using gitops features of Portainer to maintain the system and handle change management. The git repo is a private one I setup for the purposes of the project and I will be using it as a change reference to our internal change management systems.

Author: piotrsedrowski
Content:
Hi everyone! It‚Äôs great to be here. My name is Piotr.
I worked in R&D for 10 years in companies making electronics for building automation. But I was always more interested in production ‚Äì where things are actually made. A year ago, I changed my role. I still work in the same company, but now I focus on automation instead of R&D. I built the MES system, and now valuable data is being collected. At the moment, I am working on data analysis and improving integration with the ERP system. Right now, data is exchanged using text files, but I want to make this process better. I hope to learn new things here and also share my knowledge with others.
I have been following this topic on YouTube for a long time, and I find it really exciting. The idea of UNS caught my attention, but I still have some questions, which is why I joined this group. I‚Äôm really looking forward to participating in the mastermind and exchanging ideas with all of you!

Author: brave_fox_01211
Content:
Hi everyone,

I'm Ali Akremi, Shopfloor Platform Lead at a chemical company in Belgium. I manage a portfolio of solutions with my team, including Aveva PI, LIMS, and hopefully a future MES built on an IIOT platform to manage production activities. 
I subscribed to the annual program last November. Although I missed the UNS basic training, I'm now catching up through the 12-week accelerator program. I joined the program with two colleagues, Matt Northey and Daniel Liu, aiming to elevate our shopfloor operations.

Like many companies, we have major solutions such as SAP (a mix of ECC and S4 Hana), Aveva PI, LIMS, and Siemens Scada, but no MES, for which we still have to convince part of our management board to go for it. We face challenges with point-to-point connections and real-time data availability. Additionally, our IS team has ongoing discussions about the security aspects of the UNS setup, which conflicts with the good-old Purdue model they still reference(....).

I'm really happy to join this community and learn from all of you.

Author: veleznable_63540
Content:
Hello everyone! I'm Jaime, the Product Marketing Manager at **Barbara**. Barbara provides an Edge AI platform designed for operational technology (OT) environments. In plain terms, we help industrial companies bring the power of AI and data processing right to their operations (on the factory floor or at remote sites) in a secure and efficient way.

In a nutshell, our platform focuses on:

* **Enabling AI at the edge:** Running AI models on devices right where the action is (e.g. on a factory floor) for real-time insights.
* **Secure on-site data processing:** Processing data on-site in a secure way, which is crucial for OT environments with strict security requirements.
* **Enhancing industrial operations:** Improving efficiency and reliability through on-site intelligence ‚Äì basically making **Industry 4.0** a reality.

I'm excited to join this Industry 4.0 community and look forward to sharing ideas and learning from all of you about the latest in industrial innovation!

Author: mandeepsidhu2001_96284
Content:
Hi everyone
I am an Industrial Digital Transformation Consultant at Schneider Electric
My focus is initially on telemetry for critical national infrastructure in the United Kingdom using the Geo SCADA Product.
I started as a consultant month after 24 years as an Engineer and then Implementation Manager.

Many of our existing customers are looking to do more with their Geo SCADA systems, only just realising data is king. 

Some of our Geo SCADA systems are over 1m tags with tens of millions of alarm, events and time series data. Some data is 25 years old. 

I'm somewhat new to all the AVEVA technology and increasing my awareness of it, PI is front and centre of what most customers want. Probably more so CONNECT.

During my 24 year telemetry career I took a job for 5 years and worked for an Pharma OEM and developed systems in Siemens, Rockwell - I know those far better than AVEVA! 

But Geo SCADA and me go back to when it was running on VMS and called SCX2, people in the development team gave me my job when I was an Undergrad in 2001! 

My main challenge is IT OT data Convergence and UNS is interesting but our biggest challenge is aggregating hisoric data and making it available self serve.

Author: danny_phoenix
Content:
Hey everyone ‚Äî I'm Danny Phoenix, founder and developer of a new industrial software platform purpose-built for Industry 4.0 environments.

After over 20 years working directly in manufacturing, we‚Äôve built a Unified Namespace (UNS) system that combines edge and server architecture in a smart, scalable way. Our edge devices run in Docker containers on local OT networks, capturing and storing data in a local database for rapid reporting and resilient operations. A centralized server instance ‚Äî typically on the IT network ‚Äî aggregates and synchronizes this data across the plant.

One of the core innovations behind our solution is a custom-built **asset framework** that streamlines setup, simplifies asset management, and enables repeatability across equipment and lines. This isn‚Äôt just about connecting devices ‚Äî it‚Äôs about creating an ecosystem that can be maintained and expanded with confidence.

We‚Äôre not here to push one-off installs. While we‚Äôve worked on plenty of those (and with integrators who specialize in them), our real focus is **long-term plant support**. Maintaining a plant over the course of 5, 10, or more years presents entirely different challenges ‚Äî and that‚Äôs where this platform excels. Our system is designed to evolve with your operation, not become another forgotten install.

Looking ahead, we‚Äôre exploring a cloud-connected model that gives manufacturers the option to host their own databases and connect external data sources securely ‚Äî all while keeping control where it matters most.

If you're serious about building sustainable, future-ready infrastructure for manufacturing, we‚Äôre excited to connect. üë∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüîßüìà

Author: sanzor_
Content:
Hi everyone,
I am Adrian based in Bucharest, Romania.  For the past 8 years i have been architecturing/developing (soft) realtime, distributed apps in Erlang/C# and Rust.

I have been also developing for 2~ years  IoT/IIoT  desktop apps  (WPF/Winforms) and web based SCADA control systems for railway industry as well as HVAC. I have been using OPC DA (matrikon) to connect via RSLinx to Rockwell PLC's   , Schneider S7 1200 , HMI-s . I have also programmed PLC's (Siemens,Schneider, a bit of ABB)

Though i am more on the web side (backend) traditional development i love anything involving high traffic - message queues, brokers, websockets and IIoT is the place i want to be in the long term.

My ideal work would involve Erlang for distributed computing (actor oriented programming) , each actor representing a component on the factory floor , be it sensor, actuator/ motor / VFD etc üòÑ 

Github:
https://www.github.com/sanzor

Looking forward to chatting with all of you !

Author: jeffeweizen
Content:
Hello everyone! I am excited to join this community and learn from others, share ideas, and keep up to date with the latest in this industry.

My name is Jeffrey, and I have been a software developer for 3 years in manufacturing SaaS after spending the first 3 years of my career as a manufacturing engineer. As a software developer, I lead frontend and backend projects in web, desktop, and service applications. My specific areas of expertise are industrial device communication and data collection, analysis, and visualization. I enjoy working with many different technologies, learning new technologies, and leveraging my background in industrial automation to help manufacturers get the most out of their software.

As a manufacturing engineer, my primary responsibilities were to support and drive production improvements through digital transformation, data collection and analysis, and manufacturing system design. Eventually, I began working with industrial control systems and robotics. This led me to develop a passion for designing and developing software to solve problems in manufacturing and ultimately my transition to software development.

I am looking forward to contributing to and learning from this community!

Author: josephw96
Content:
Hi everyone! I‚Äôm Joseph, Head of Growth at UDMTEK USA, an industrial automation software company that my father founded and still leads in Korea. I‚Äôve currently paused my career in the hedge fund industry to help my father expand our US business. As I learn about this entirely new industry, I thought I‚Äôd join this great community to accelerate my learning and make new friends along the way.

Briefly about my company -  we‚Äôve developed the world‚Äôs first PLC programming language technology that can extract and convert low-level languages from different PLC makers into a higher-level, unified language. This gives controls and automation engineers a level of insight that was never possible before. We call it Machine Language Processing‚Äîsimilar to Natural Language Processing like Google Translate, but for PLCs. Unlike existing solutions that rely solely on sensor data, our ability to add data directly from the PLC provides engineers with far superior diagnostics and predictive maintenance tools.

I‚Äôm excited to join this community and look forward to learning from all of you. Thank you!

Content:
Hey everyone! I‚Äôm Ray from South Carolina, currently working as a Systems Engineer.
I started my career as an intern in the steel industry and eventually rolled (no pun intended) into a full-time role in their OT department. I spent 7 years at that company before joining a system integrator.

Author: joypink
Content:
Hi, all! I'm a software engineer who recently officially entered the manufacturing space. (My undergrad is in manufacturing engineering, and my grad degree is Computer Science). First job was game dev, then full stack software engineering. I just started a new job five weeks ago. My team's goal is to bring our manufacturing from paper and Excel to a digital factory.

Is there a roadmap to a digital factory from scratch? What are some good resources? I've been watching videos on the YouTube Channel, but is there a book or a beginning-to-end series I can watch, too?

Thanks!

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Welcome Joy! We are glad you are here! What problems are you currently facing?!  That would help me better direct you.  The answer of the top of my head is our Mastermind program, but i want to make sure i fully understand your problem before recommending a solution.

Author: thehmiguy
Content: What videos specifically from the 4.0 YouTube Channel have you watched? That will help avoid duplicating efforts. I have some that come to mind.

Author: joypink
Content:
I have just been putting them on and listening on autoplay! I'm taking in a lot of information, but don't remember the specific videos. I'd like to learn more about the UNS in particular. 

As for problems I'm facing - my team was very small, and didn't really know how to build a product. So when I started, I was able to really quickly build out a little tool that will help our CI team a lot. I don't know a lot about manufacturing yet, but I am good at asking questions.

This is going to be our first small win, and leadership is super excited about our path forward! But I am going to be doing a lot of the heavy lifting for building out tools,  investigating pain points from our citizen developers... ultimately, my goal is to become a digital factory SME. 

I think the real problem is... there just isn't a lot of knowledge of what rthe digital factory needs to look like! Just that we want one. So I'm taking it on myself to learn as much as I can.

Author: joypink
Content: I apologize for how vague this is. I am in the "learning enough to ask a useful question" phase, haha.

Author: thehmiguy
Content: What SCADA platform are you using? Any aspect of a MES application, or is everything manual in this layer of the stack?

Author: joypink
Content:
We are using Ignition. I really like building apps with it because it's a lot like another software I use. 

We have an internally-built MES application (my understand, could be wrong) that takes in raw data from users and sends it to a cloud database. However, we aren't really doing anything with that data once we get it.

Content: Now, what manual inputs/Excel integrations are you trying to eliminate?

Author: kvaneenennaam
Content: If you're learning Ignition this is my beginner guide on what free resources to start with - https://www.reddit.com/r/PLC/comments/1h304uj/my_take_on_how_to_learn_ignition_from_scratch/

Author: joypink
Content:
Adding that resource to my list!

I am still finding out! this is only my fifth week. From what I *have* seen, a lot of our manually-entered data is entered incorrectly sometimes, and I am wanting to make an AI system that will flag anomolous data and notify someone to fix it. I have a good path forward for that.

Still too early in learning our processes to say. But I know it takes us forever to get reports out the door because we have too much stuff moving around on paper and in peoples' heads.

=

Author: thehmiguy
Content: What manual data are the operators entering? Specifically, can that be automated to remove the human error? For example, if an operator had to manually measure a part,  you'd be better off with a controls solution (e.g., laser, vision system, etc) to automatically capture the data, and then Ignition can insert that into the database, which can be used later for reports. This is just one example, but might be best to focus on the points where the manual data is being entered by a human and remove it (if possible).

Author: thehmiguy
Content: Basically, my point is, a simple controls solution COULD save you $$$ and time vs implementing an AI system when there's devices that are designed for certain manual tasks.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Thanks for sharing Ray. üôè

Author: zack.scriven
Content: What is your role within the company?

Author: joypink
Content:
I'm  a Sr. Specialist Manufacturing Engineer on the Automation team (colliquially called the Digital Factory team). My team only has two other people, and neither are technical enough to build software. They also can't really design a software product, and a lot of what I'm going to be building out are tools. The buzzword "Single Pane of Glass" is getting used a lot. My main collaborator has been a member of the continuous improvement team, who has been working with me closely on the design of the prototype I recently built.

One example I know of so far that gets manually entered and has high innaccuracy is the serial number of a given part. It seems like metadata gives us the most issues - I believe we have some controls that automatically send out data.

I agree that solving the issue at the source would be ideal. But I think an AI solution could be a good stop-gap while I build trust, especially since there are some AI tools built into our data storage software.

Author: alex895438
Content:
Hello everyone! 
I'm Alex Arias, Smart Manufacturing & Automation Manager at Texas Instruments. 
I work across the full data stack - from tool sensors using OPC-UA and SECS/GEM protocols, through ETL pipelines and orchestration tools like Airflow and Spark, up to data lake technologies like S3 and Databricks, and finally to BI tools like Spotfire, JMP, and Tableau. 
I've built scalable data systems across manufacturing, fintech, and adtech - automated underwriting pipelines, fraud detection systems, real-time ad campaign optimization, and Kubernetes-based microservices. Started as a process engineer at TI doing defect analysis and statistical process control, then moved through various data engineering roles before coming back to TI in the data/automation space.
Background is Materials Science & Engineering from University of Florida, with recent certifications in ML and data engineering from Databricks. Technical stack includes Python, React, Javascript, SQL, Go, Kubernetes, Jenkins, Redshift, and various ML pipeline tools.
Looking forward to sharing experiences about what's working in manufacturing's digital transformation - particularly around making advanced analytics accessible to non-technical users and building robust data pipelines that can handle real-time sensor data at scale.

Author: raghav.bhardwaj.1
Content:
Hey everyone! üëã 

I‚Äôm a final-year software engineering student, and I started out as an intern at the same company I‚Äôm still with today. My first project was building an internal app to automate our fiber optic testing, which was originally done manually on the production line.

That project gave me a solid understanding of how things run on the production testing ground, and now me and my team have been given a much bigger responsibility/opportunity of building a full MES system for the entire company (i.e.: raw materials to finished goods). 

Industry 4.0 helped us pitch the idea of developing our own custom platform and got the approval! Since then, we‚Äôve been working on building tools/apps to digitize and organize production and quality control testing processes for operators and engineers. 

Our current challenge is carefully implementing a unified database/namespace (going from CSVs to Database).

On top of the technical side, a big part of the challenge is also cultural ‚Äî working closely with different teams, getting their input, and making sure we‚Äôre not just forcing a new system on them, but building something they want to use.

I joined this server to learn more about MES, see how others are approaching similar problems, and hopefully share some ideas too. 

Awesome to be here! üíØ

Author: steveguerard
Content:
Hi everyone,

I am Steve Gu√©rard, a professional industrial engineer, amateur software developer, and a true believer that productivity is the key to improving human living conditions.

Driven by this belief, I‚Äôve made it my mission to study and apply productivity techniques in manufacturing, taking time to read and draw ideas from manufacturing pioneers such as Henry Ford, Taiichi Ohno, and Shigeo Shingo. 

I've also had a long-standing interest in computer science, and as I advanced in learning programming, I found myself asking how this technology could be used to enhance productivity in manufacturing. But when I started to read about Industry 4.0, I didn‚Äôt know what I was getting myself into, and I‚Äôve come to truly appreciate it ‚Äî to me, it‚Äôs the new frontier for driving productivity. I had my ‚Äúred pill moment‚Äù listening to Walker and Zack‚Äôs content, which led me to join the IIoT University Pro Membership program to deepen my understanding.

I‚Äôm currently working at Stelpro, an electric heating appliance manufacturer based in Qu√©bec, Canada. My team‚Äôs role is to support production through new product introductions and improvement projects, but as we continue our journey, I expect to become increasingly involved in the company‚Äôs digital transformation efforts. 

I'm glad to be part of this community and I look forward to sharing with you.

Author: christoff7409
Content:
Hi folks,

my name is Hristo and I have 7+ years experience in the digitalization of manufacturing processes with a focus on data operations. My experience spreads across the board: data mining, data extraction, data engineering all the way to predictive analytics, reporting and a bit of GenAI chatbot development for operator support. I have worked extensively with Ignition and also have experience with Power Apps for process digitalization with custom backends. My career initially started in IT as a business analyst but I was fortunate enough to end up in Industry 4.0 üôÇ Previously I worked for Atlas Copco as Smart Factory Engineer and now I work for Jabil Healthcare.

Author: alexbmsf
Content:
Hey everyone! üëã

I'm Alex Bolton-Mijares, Automation Engineer at Stacked Farm based on the Goldcoast, Australia. I graduated from Griffith University with a degree in Electrical & Electronic Engineering and have been diving deep into the world of vertical farming automation.

My journey has taken me through various roles - from game development/software development to metal fabrication and then to solar engineering, Ignition/Systems Integration, and now I'm tackling the unique challenges of automating controlled environment agriculture and robotics. I work extensively with Ignition for SCADA development and Python for data control, building systems that help optimize growing conditions in our vertical farms.

What really excites me is bridging the gap between theoretical concepts and practical applications. At Stacked Farm, we're pushing the boundaries of what's possible in agricultural automation, dealing with everything from environmental controls to data acquisition at scale.

I've been following Walker and Zack's content on YouTube (absolute game-changers!) and am keen to learn more about UNS implementation and best practices for building robust Industry 4.0 infrastructure. Particularly interested in how others are tackling MQTT Transmission (UNS), building operator-friendly interfaces, and creating truly unified namespaces across diverse systems.

Looking forward to connecting with this community and sharing experiences about what's working (and what's not) in manufacturing's digital transformation!

Author: dylangrafmyre8250
Content: Hello Everyone ü§ô,  I am a Ski Lift Mechanic at Powder Mountain. Prior to working on ski lifts my background for 26 yrs was in Super Computer operations/administration, Web Application Software Development,  DevOps, Project and Software Developer Management and CTO. After, the last startup closed shop, I decided to make a huge career pivot and moved into Lift Maintenance. I discovered a whole industry still using a paper based system with no data collection or operation insight from Lift PLCs, and absence of any sensor deployment on critical hardware. All paper work orders, annual maintenance, and operations inspections where just in a filing cabinet. I was able to work with management start a digital transformation by moving from paper to Limble CMMS for all our maintenance tasks and parts inventory management. We are now starting a two, ski lift test case for the winter ski season of building out our the connect, collect, store phase with adding an Ignition Gateway, Ignition Edge at each ski lift and using MQTT to publish tags from lift plcs, and deployed vibration/temperature sensors monitoring our critical mechanical hardware in the ski lift terminals. This will be the first time a ski lift maintenance department in our area will have real time monitoring of our lifts during winter operations.  I look forward to learning so much form this community and will have lots of questions along the way. I am excited about our team taking steps to realize a complete Industry 4.0 transformation for the lift maintenance department and bleeding over to the whole resort.

Author: brian.mccarver_52117
Content:
Hello all.

I have undergrad and master's degrees from UofL Speed School. For 5 or 6 years I worked as a Controls/Apps Engineer for a small firm in Louisville Kentucky that primarily develops test and reliability systems for appliance manufacturers. After that employment I moved into a Machine Vision System Designer and Developer role at an electronics connector and cable assembly manufacturer in New Albany Indiana. I performed that role for about 6 and half years before moving into the Controls department at the same company.  In that role I developed a recipe management solution for an asset type with 150 instances spread across various sites around the globe. In that solution I leveraged the MQTT connector in the HMI to publish recipe change data to AWS IoT Core which triggered a Lambda that pushed updates to the recipe database. That caught the attention of the manager and director of the company's IIoT team. I am now in an IIoT Developer role. 

I've watched tons of YouTube videos related to UNS and IIoT for the past year and three months.  I've learned a lot and am still learning. I'm starting to work with others in the company to stand up our first two POC's. Now that I'm spending real time considering the problems we are trying to solve and the implementation details I'm coming up with questions for the community. 

Thank you all for your participation here.  I've read through quite few threads based on questions I've already had.  I'm planning to post some questions here soon.  

Thank you!

Content:

right now I‚Äôm exploring how AI agents can sense ‚Üí decide ‚Üí act in industrial contexts, and how IT abstractions can bridge with OT realities. super excited to exchange ideas, learn from real deployments, and contribute where I can. üöÄ

Author: exception06lizzybusy_48596
Content:
Hey everyone, this is Liz, one of the founders of ErgoTech Systems. We are a scrappy innovator with established experience in data collection and tool connectivity for semiconductor manufacturing, and we are now expanding into other industrial verticals with a new product designed to improve the digital transformation experience, especially for manufacturers with lower digital maturity. Some of you I may have already met at OT SCADA CON, AIMST, or other events we attended over the summer.

I am looking to have a few short offline conversations (10‚Äì15 minutes) with people in industrial automation and manufacturing. The goal is not to pitch software but to understand current challenges, whether that is how AI may reshape industrial automation and manufacturing, or whether other issues are even more important. We have a few hypotheses we are testing, but I am equally interested in hearing directly from you guys about what matters most.

If you would be open to a brief discussion, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to connect.
